text: I am from philly and have eaten many steaks and have never gotten ill from it. Something isn't right with Pats. I don't know if it's the freshness of the condiments or ingredients or the cleanliness of the grill and staff but we were both sick for 2-3 days after eating there. Food poisoning matters and more people need to report this if it's happening after they eat here. So unfortunate. They are quickly serving so many tourists and Philadelphians without slowing down and assessing the problems.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
This is the second time I've been to Pat's and the first stop in Philadelphia this weekend with my boyfriend. 

Don't be intimidated by the crowd. There's not much to choose from (aka "wit" onions or "witout", a couple of cheeses) so once you decide you tell them, give them your money, and get your food, all within 20 seconds. They really have perfected the system. There is hardly any wait. 

It could have been because my boyfriend and I were hungry, but I preferred this over Geno's. The bread was toasted making the overall sandwich much better tasting. However, you can add ketchup, mustard, relish, and hot peppers if you desire (all toppings are DIY and free). 

It is very expensive. I believe we paid $9.50 for a cheesesteak sandwich, but we shared and went to Geno's to compare. 

I did enjoy the outdoor seating, but we lucked out. There isn't always space.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Over 9 dollars for a shoe leather of a steak? Yeah, this place is a tourist trap for out of towners who believe this place  (and that other pit across the street) serve the best cheesesteaks. At least the racism/xenophobia is not apparent here (unlike that pit across the street).
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
When you hear or talk about Philadelphia, the first thought that comes to mind are Philadelphia Cheesesteaks. With its rival (Gino's) located across the street, it's hard to rule out which of the two are better. Nonetheless, we've decided to try Pat's where visitors, tourists and locals assemble in a line (that wrapped around the block) to await for the glorious moment of biting into an original Philadelphia Cheesesteak. 

A few things to remember -- there are STRICT guidelines on how to order at Pat's:
Step 1 - State if you want steak or onions on your cheesesteak: "wit" or "wit-out". 
Step 2 - choose your cheese: Plain, American, Provolone, Cheese Steak, "wit wiz" (cheez wiz) or "wit-out" (no cheez).
Step 3 - Have your money ready (IN YOUR HAND, not in your purse or pockets).
Step 4 - If you mess up any of the above steps, "you can wait and try it again when you return from the back of the line". 
Note - There are two windows; the first is where you order your cheesesteak and the second is where you order the other things for your cheesesteak -- like fries and soda. 

FOOD - "One Cheesesteak wit American wit onions". Our steak was a bit tough, chewy and bland as if it had been sitting on the grill for quite some time before being served instead of that greasy, moist and tender steak we've heard so much about. We were a bit disappointed with the outcome since we've travelled from NYC for this, but I guess that's what happens when you're trying to serve 20 customers per minute throughout the day. 

We'll try again another time, but I wouldn't come back anytime soon. However, I wouldn't discourage anyone from trying Pat's if they've never had it before. It's something that you still MUST TRY when you're around the area and who knows - maybe you'll get a really moist, juicy and tender cheesesteak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I LOVE THEIR PHILLY CHEESESTEAK! 

The thing between the two rivalry joints of Pats and Genos, is that this place doesn't scream out when you first look at the place. Its more relaxed and chilled to dine into compare to the very flashy Geno's. If I were to visit Philadelphia again in the future, I definitely won't be choosing side because I love both spots. They just have their own specific style of cooking and presenting their own philly cheesesteak.

Pat's KIng of Steaks Philly Cheesesteak was just perfection. The bread was simple and tasty. The steak was cooked and sliced to perfection, it was juicy just the way it should be. The cheese wasn't too overwhelming but it had that ooey gooey feeling right when you first bite into it. *drool Gosh, reviewing these two philly cheesesteak makes me crave it even more. Too bad I have not found a good Philly Cheesesteak here in Los Angeles, CA. If anyone knows a place, please do recommend.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
authentic philly cheese steak: bread, meat, cheese wiz.

i dont think ive had more than 5 cheese steaks in my life but this was pretty good. the dirtier the better right?
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Old fashioned quality cheesesteaks with none of the hype and flare that surrounds the belligerent neighbor across the street.

Still the best Cheesesteak by far. Skip Geno's and just sample the history that is Pat's.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: In the cheesesteak war, my vote is for Pat's over Geno's.  The key factor?  The steak itself; Pat's was slightly thicker cut, which gave it a bit more bite, and it seemed to have more flavor to boot.  On the bread side Geno's had the edge, but overall the sandwich was better here.  I also liked the seating better here, but that's a minor advantage really...
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Good cheesesteak but did not live up to the hype. I did like this cheesesteak SLIGHTLY better than Genos but I wanted more toppings and flavors. Still good, fun and recommended. Make sure to get whiz wit'.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I just went  on Easter Sunday to try out these famous cheese steaks. My boyfriend's mother had an injured knee and even she thought the atrocious line was worth the wait. The atmosphere almost made me lose my appetite a few times, but that came rushing back as soon as I got to the front of the line. I would even say some of the characters waiting in line with you make the experience sincere. I was really worried about the ordering process, but in actuality they aren't that ruthless. With a line that wrapped around ... twice ... they still allowed a woman to fumble over the ordering and payment process. This place works like a well-oiled machine.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Impromptu lunch date here today with the wife. I sampled the regular chess team with onions and provolone. She had the mushroom with cheese whiz and onions. We both found the sandwich to be tasteful and fulfilling. The roll seemed like it came bagged from a grocery store. Afterwards we lived over to Geno's for the true taste test. See Geno's review for winner.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: If you are a tourist, you will need to go to Pat's and Geno's and pick a side.  I myself, like Geno's steaks better.  I'm not a cheese whiz on my steak kind of guy.  That being said, I like Pat's fries with the cheese sauce in them better.  Honestly, they are both good, a must if you've never been, and a Philly institution.  You need to go, if no better reason than its history.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: My first Philly cheesesteak. I decided to try the normal with Provolone cheese which was good, but my friend got the wit wiz and it was yummy. I will always get wit wiz when visiting philly
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Review is for cheese fries only.  Fries are the only option for vegetarians here.  Fries were delicious, large, well salted and fried just right.  Regular cheese fries came with enough cheese, no need for the extra cheese.  Enjoyed eating my cheese fries while my S/O had his cheesesteak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: No longer my reigning champ... My #2 Cheesesteak Place. Still consistently delicious, even at 5:00 Am !
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Great food,  rude customer service,  lady taking orders was short on patience and so was the drink lady
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I'm a tourist from Indianapolis visiting for work. We did the Pat's vs. Geno's taste test. Pat's wins. There's something about the saltiness of the meat and slight seasoning to the whiz.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I almost feel bad for vegetarians.  I mean how could you roll up to Philly and not order a cheese steak from Pat's or one of the other famous places??

The cheese steak was delicious, but i wanted more for my $9.  I'm really complaining though, i feel like eating at Pat's is an experience in itself.  This is a place you see on TV after all!

Make sure you know the lingo though.  There's a specific method of ordering a sandwich (I'm not going to type it out, look it up!) and you will be ignored if you don't use it.  Don't worry though, instructions are on the building.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I love it! Authentic Philadelphia specialty! Great before a concert and or a ball game.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: love love this famous & traditional philly establishment! Watch out for the pigeons and bring cash. Practice your order in line and dig in!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Steak was tough, grissly... Maybe an off day or a bad cut of meat but wasn't impressed and DO NOT understand all of the hype. Sorry Phili... No disrespect.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: City landmark and tradition. I used to frequent this place late at night when I lived in the city. Lots of memories or me here. Now I have  family I take my kids here when I am n the city.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Good cheesesteak but service leaves something to be desired. In philly, you're either a Pat's or a Geno's fan. I'm firmly on the Pat's bandwagon. They love their veterans and even refused to take my money when I was in uniform. Class place and worth a least one visit when you're in the Philadelphia area.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Had the standard Philly Cheesesteak. I went to Pat's and Geno's on my first trip to Philly, and I must say Pat's wins hands down. They made what I asked for fresh unlike Geno's, the steak flavor was much better, and I like that they have many sides you can take with you. The peppers are essential, add a few to your cheesesteak to spice it up. Good Stuff here.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Disclaimer: We are mostly vegetarians.

So we decided to eat some meat while in Philly. You can't go to Philly and not have a cheesesteak at one of the famous local joints can you? We checked out both Geno's and Pat's to compare :)

We got a cheesesteak with onions and wiz and fries from both places. 

The flavor of the meat and the bread was better at Pat's, and possibly the fries. But to the overall package was a bit better at Geno's. Very little seating.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: there are better places that make and to eat cheese steaks.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
When in Philly, visit Pat's
Have cash.
Know how to order and BE READY
As with a lot of tourist spots, it's important to keep something in mind : Pat's is good because you're THERE - emersed in the energy of the city of brotherly love.  It won't be the best sandwich you've ever had, but in the moment (with the finches scavenging for bread bits at your feet) it's absolutely perfect.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Definitely the soup nazi of cheesesteaks.  Know what you are ordering before getting to the counter or else they'll send you away.  I appreciate that it makes the line go faster! 

I could have used a bit more meat on my sandwich, but besides for that I can't really complain!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: absolutely horrible. i do not recommend this place at all. there's gotta be much better cheesesteaks.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Initially did not want to come here, given their reputation for long lines, and probability of being refused of service. But a friend's friend (let's call him Bob) wanted to come here or Geno's bad, so we indulged and I suggested Pat's instead. Came here around 5-6pm, with yes.. long lines, after a long walk here, knowing parking will be nearly impossible. Lined up for nearly 20 minutes (which was much better than I expected). 

I was first in line ordering for the glf as well, as we sent her and her pals to wrestle some crowds for an opened table. With my arm already extended with exact change in hand, I yelled out "2 Provolone wit" and quickly sidestep efficiently down the line as they took my money. In less than a minute, I got two hot steaks in hand. 

Bob, who was right behind me wasn't so lucky. He froze indecisively for few seconds when he was asked to order. He then blurted out "what cheese do you guys have again?" I instantly face palmed myself hearing that, saying to myself "oh boy..." The guy half shrugged with a headshake and direct his attention to the next person in line for his order. Just like that.. poor Bob was sent to the back of the line. 

Luckily the glf and her friends found a table as I scrambled out with the steaks. In a cold night, the warm steaks were perfect to have. Until, we took our first bite, and then eventually to the last. The steaks really were "average". I seriously have had better steaks in even California. And for the price, wait and for some, the stress in ordering, it was absolutely not worth it. 

In conclusion, the place is all hyped. But I was glad I've tried it and can say I have tried the subpar Pat's experience in Philly. Meanwhile Bob sat starved, rejected and watch us ate our cheesesteaks. The good news for him was, he didn't ended up over paying for a subpar cheesesteak like we did. We also tried Jim's which was a tat better, but with a much better and polite staff.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Better than Geno's imo, but hardly the best cheesesteak in Philly (but everyone will give you a different opinion in this city). It is an A-OK cheesesteak if you are in the area and in the mood, or from out of town and want to hit up the touristy spot. Other than that, if you are looking for a real mind blowing cheesesteak do some research! Area is OK. When its less busy I've been harassed by kids selling chocolates and looking to make a quick buck.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: No great cheesesteak can be assembled in less time than it takes to order.  It breaks my heart than so many tourists will know little more than Pat's and similarly inadequate, corner-cutting, canned-attitude sort of establishments.  They are open late, which is a plus and they are preferable to Geno's. But best in Philly?  Not a bloody chance.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I never write reviews....but I just had to. I've lived in Philadelphia my whole life. I know it's a tourist attraction but honestly, please save your money and your health. My go to steak is American Without....well, if you're interested in a stale, cold roll, with a cold piece of American cheese, and a nice heap of undercooked/diseased "steak" with more yellow fat than actual steak, then this your go to place - oh and don't forget to bring $20 so you can also get your frozen french fries that are cooked in week old oil. I've tried giving Pats and Geno's many opportunities to redeem themselves over the last decade. It seems as if they get worse and worse. I don't know how people eat this nor do I understand how someone hasn't died yet. They handle your food with the same hands that take your money. This place should be illegal and is an embarrassment to Philadelphia. Wawa serves a better cheesesteak than Pat's. I would honestly eat the boiled meat cheesesteak from Wawa or any corner joint over this atrocity. You want a cheesesteak that will make you reconsider your idea of good food? Stop by Steve's Prince of Steaks and join the locals at the best cheesesteak joint in the city - no joke.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Customer service is horrible the Philly cheesesteak it's nothing special No taste no flavor just smells and taste like it was drenched in oil.never ever coming back here again The services doesn't  make things any better
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Jim's? Pat's? Geno's? I've never been to Jim's but I think that's where I'd rather be compared to those other two losers.

Everyone loves Pat's better. Why didn't it live up to it's name? I walked a long way to get there, stood in a longass line, let the man touch my sandwich after he handled my money (no gloves at all) and sat on a stoop while grease and cheese dripped all over the ground. It was unsanitary at its best.

My whiz wit and mushroom cheesesteak was a colossal disappointment. Why don't they chop up the meat? Are there tendons in it? I was pulling out huge chunks of fat and ligament types off of my steak. The meat was tough, it was bland and the sandwich overall was cold. Plus, my mushrooms looked like they came out of a can. Pooey.

Wack. Philly may be the birthplace of the cheesesteak but like all other copycats, I'm almost betting that some of the wannabes improved on the recipe. In fact I know where the better cheesesteak lives and it's my secret (to be revealed in my review of Geno's)!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Sorry, but not the best cheesesteaks around.  The last time I was there was probably the last time I will ever be there.  There was so much gristle in them that I was really turned off.  Pretty embarrassing too since we brought some out-of-towners with us.  Fries were good though.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Cheese
Steak
Bread

how can you go wrong with that combination??  being as touristy as we can,  my sister and i practiced the "local" lingo and made sure we ordered our steak with WHIZ.  def not for the faint of heart.  

the steak pieces were thick and juicy and filled up to both ends of the bread roll, the whiz on top was the cherry on the icing.  you know you got yourself some good grub when you feel the grease, taste the grease and still keep shoving the food down.  

though we were ambitious to do an iron chef competition of genos vs pats.  we were both too stuffed to attempt a second cheesesteak.  next time ...
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Living in Brooklyn, I had this insane craving for a cheesesteak, we have them here, but after living in south jerz for a while, I don't buy them up north. So filled the tank and headed to Philly. My normal spot is Gaetanos in south jerz, but I figured I'm driving 100 miles, it better be authentic. After debating, I decided on Pats. I got a with American.The bread was soft on the inside, and a slight crunch on the outside (YUM!) Something about Philly white american, I can eat that cheese all day. Cant find that same kind in BK. The steak was ok, nothing spectacular. And the onions were good. Have I had better, definitely. But I knew what I was comming for, and after 100 miles, Pats definitly satisfied. Between Genos and Pats, I'm Pats all the way. But, if you know a local, they can show you a better cheesesteak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Myself and 3 friends decided to do a cheesesteak taste tour of Philly to determine which place had the best cheesesteak. We picked the top 5 yelp locations, went to each one on concession, ordered exactly the same item at each place (cheesesteak with Provolone cheese and grilled onions), split it in 4 and gave our verdict. Findings as follows (in order of preference):

#1 - Sonny's: soft bread, delicious cheese and flavorful meat. Our absolute fave. Next time we'd consider asking for more cheese to make it even more perfect.

#2 - Pat's: a close 2nd. In comparison to Sonny's, the bread was slightly chewier, the cheese was more prominent tasting (an advantage over Sonny's), the onions tasteful but the meat was slightly greasier.

#3 - Ishkabibble: the meat was on the dryer side and lacking in cheese quantity. Bread was decent and chewy. Flavor was decent.

#4 - Geno's: food was a little bland and on the greasier side. Despite this, the cheesesteak was still tastey, but not our top choice. 

#5 - Jim's: the greasiest of all the cheesesteaks with the blandest meat. I would skip.

Hopefully our little taste testing endeavor will help anyone visiting Philly for a brief time, looking to try the best cheesesteaks this city has to offer.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: This is probably a place for the tourists. I found the onion, pepper, mushroom toppings were limp and soggy. They do not have the roasted/pan fried flavors I was looking for because of the mass production. The street side picnic tables  benches, large garbage cans and heavy traffic in front of it is quite festive if you are looking for that kind of experience. The area is very busy (with Geno's across the street), finding a parking space was a chore.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Every time I go to Philadelphia I go to Pat's and Geno's Steaks. All other times I've been there it's been great but not so much this time.

The location is 5 blocks east of Ellsworth-Federal Station on the SEPTA Broad Street Line. It isn't a scary walk from the restaurants (9th & Passyunk) to the station.

After a long line, like usual, I got my steaks. I got a steak w/ onions & no cheese. The Pat's sandwich was good, the meat was juicy and the onions were warm. The Geno's Steak had no onions, so the meat was dry and left out the warmth of the onion. 

If I had to choose between the two, I would give Pat's 3.5 to 4 stars & Geno's 2 to 2.5 stars which leaves me with a 3-star rating.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
There are plenty of reviews before me so I won't elaborate much (which is quite contrary to my normal reviews).

I give both Pat's and Geno's the Grade A Stamp of a Tourist Trap.

You get a lot of meat and it comes with cheese.  For the price, the sandwich is MUCH smaller than any other cheese steak joint in Philadelphia.  You will find that the steak floats in a pool of grease within the roll.  Never have I eaten a cheesesteak where I could basically tilt the sandwich and watch a steady stream of clear grease splatter on the street.

If you're getting any type of cheese other than Whiz, they don't even bother to melt the cheese on the steak.

Of course, if you're a tourist go here to say you've been.  And if you're from the area and have never been, it is a nice stroll through the Italian Market to reach Pat's.

But seriously, don't bother if you're looking for a cheese steak one afternoon.  $7 for a 10" provolone without, please.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
The great Pat's vs. Geno's debate.

That's what a co-worker and I hoped to resolve when we made the quickest pit stop ever en route to catching our train out of the city.  Pat's.  Geno's.  Quite simply, a LOT of beef, cheese whiz, and bread to put down--all in 20 minutes.  (Luckily, there were no lines this Thursday evening.)

First was Pat's.  $8.25 for a cheesesteak with whiz, no onions/pepeprs/etc.  Soft, yet crisp, fresh bread--nice.  Pleasantly surprised at how well the whiz worked.  But the meat, served in rough chunks, was a little tough and not that flavorful.  Good, but onto Geno's...

Geno's.  I was wary of this place's reputation for in-your-face politics.  The "Take Back Our Country" signs were a little eyebrow-raising, but beyond that, nothing crazy.  Plus, this steak was damn good.  The meat here was neatly sliced, properly cooked, and well seasoned.  My co-worker raved about the hot sauce he loaded onto his.

I understand that Pat's & Geno's are considered tourist traps by Philly natives, but nonetheless, are definitely worth checking out for the history.  Pat's vs. Geno's?  One man's opinion: advantage, Geno's.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
If you are in Philly and you are looking for a Cheese steak sandwich, you kind of have to go to Pat's.  I mean, it's where they started.  It's tradition.  It's expected.  You will get a respectable and tasty mound of meat, some cheese on an adequate roll.  It won't be the best steak you'll ever have, but it won't be the worst.  

There will be a line.  The pressure from the instructions on the wall telling you how to order will bring back Seinfeld memories of the Soup Nazi.  In the end, it's all good.  They will help you with your order and you will be able to say that you ate at Pat's.  Not doing so would be like going to Hollywood and not getting your picture taken with the sign.  

The seating is outdoors, parking is on the street and there are lots of condiments.  Grab some extra napkins because you will need them.  I liked that the meat was chopped but overall was a bit under-whelmed.  I did like Pat's sandwich better than Geno's.  

They did not slice my order into 3rds as requested, so we were pulling the sandwich apart for our side by side comparison with Geno's.

If you do go here, spend some time wandering straight up the street into the Italian neighborhood.  There are a couple of nice coffee shops right on the corner to greet you and have a cannoli.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I have visited this place yearly for 18  plus years. The quality and quantity has taken a turn for the worst. I can buy a better sandwich in Reading Pa for  a third of the cost.   On my last trip I had to open my roll to see the meat. I purchased 3 steaks  fries and sodas. If I'm paying over $30.00 bucks for sandwiches they should be awesome. . The steak was flavorless!!! That's the end of my steak excursions!!!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
When visiting Philly with a 17 year old boy who watches a lot of "Food Network" you've gotta check this place out.... even if you've heard it's not that great.

The line is pretty long, but it moves quickly. There's only outdoor seating. And, the guy behind the counter who takes the order is grumpy and rude.

The cheesesteak (with American cheese and onions, please) was kinda tough, kinda greasy, and not nearly as flavorful as we had hoped. Hey.... at least we had the experience.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Visiting from LA. I had a reg philly cheese steak w onions n cheese wiz. It was good. I also got some over priced fries, reg ones and others that had cheese just pumped into them. The attitude doesn't have to be there but I think they're just trying to keep that rude feel going. Think "soup natzi" from Seinfeld. Whatever. Give me my shhh... The stocky jalapeños were a nice addition. Glad I didn't get charged for those. No line when I went. I'd try something different next time.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I read about Pat's on line and was recommended to me from a friend of mine that lived in the area.  I got off the airplane, rented my car and drove straight over on my way to work.  

I ordered a Steak and Provolone.  Dumped some Hot Sauce on it and went to town.

There might be better, but for me this was a decent cheesesteak.

Took a picture of the Sylvester Stalone plauqe and went along my way stuffed and happy.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Obviously, The KING.  Although perhaps not the most tender or highest quality cheesesteak in town it still reigns supreme.  
Best hours of operation anywhere, best wiz sauce of any establishment and their cheese fries are excellent.
The part i like the most when compared to any other steak places is the line aspect.  You may wait in line at pat's for a while but once you hit the window, order and pay you immediately receive your food.
Also, unlike Geno's, Pat's puts the wiz over the top of the steak meat so that the cheese cascades over the meat and entire sandwich.  This is the way to assemble the proper cheese steak, by putting the wiz on the roll like Genos the cheese is not well distributed and makes for a dry and less enjoyable sandwich.  
Lots of other good spots in town but when its 4 am and you have that jones for a cheesesteak there is no substitute.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Famous, but not sure why. 

Got the whiz wit.
-bread barely chewable
-steak underwhelming
-whiz bad

Had to load w ketchup to make edible.

Someone point me to the REAL King of Steaks!



**Pat's would get 1 star if I could give Gino's 0.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Tried Pat's when I first moved to Philadelphia to experience the whole cheese steak craze. I will admit it was a tasty cheese steak, however I became extremely ill a few hours after eating the sandwich. So ill that I had a fever for a night and was sweating profusely in my sleep. I have a pretty strong iron stomach but this one really took it out of me :( I'm not sure if this was a bad day at Pat's or if this is the regular quality of the food. Either way, I won't be visiting this Philly landmark anytime soon.

Stick to Jim's Steaks or John's Roast Pork.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Pat's King of Steaks is one the best places to get a Philly Cheese Steak.  Though I don't have a lot of experience with Cheese Steak, I do believe that the Authenticity of this place enhances the dining experience.  There is no coddling of the patrons as they are serious when you aren't prepared to know your order and you have quite a bit of time in line to figure it out...with instructions!  Rude?  Not at all, it's all part of the experience.  The food is good but not memorable.  The meat is slightly bland with condiments an absolute necessity.  Overall, tasty and fun experience.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Whoever gave either Pat's or Geno's 5 stars have obviously never dined at the Great Steak and Potato Co. at any mall's food court. I'm convinced that the only people who eat cheesesteaks in Philly are tourists. It's similar to how people who live in Chicago never eat deep dish pizza unless a friend is visiting. 

These sandwiches were overpriced and mediocre at best. The meat was dry and the only enjoyable quality was the dousing of cheese whiz. The outdoor seating sucked any remaining heat from our souls. 

I will give my obligatory opinion that I thought Pat's was much better than Geno's. Also points to the cashier for calling my friend "doll" in a deep Philadelphian accent.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Since I wrote about Geno's, I'll be fair and write about Pat's to urge you not to go there too, unless you're drunk at 4 am and get the late night munchies.  Even so, I'd rather have Lorenzo's pizza for late night feasting than this monstrosity.

I lived across the street from Pat's for 2 years and probably ate there twice, and was very much unimpressed.  The last straw for me was when I ran over there in the pouring rain to satisfy a cheese fries craving and the guy at the window said if I wasn't with the group of 70 people currently ordering, I would have to wait until their ENTIRE PARTY was finished ordering.  I vowed never to give them my business again, and found out later that J&J Pizza just up the street gave a huge portion of cheese fries for much cheaper.  They also have cheesesteaks there, but as I always say, Ishkabibbles is the place to go.

The assembly-line method of assembling cheesesteaks makes for seriously inconsistent products... Ishkabibbles makes each steak to order which takes longer but is worth it!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
have tried cheesesteaks at many different philly joints - and have to say "I. LOVE. PATS"

The hot sauce is terrific and so are the little peppers.

Line gets long at times - especially after bars close.  but would get a Pats any day
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I'm sorry to say this, but the one I had was a little dry and not all that tender. Maybe it's because it's sliced thicker.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Worth the trip to experience an institution. It is not fine dining but it is the real taste of Philadelphia in all its glory!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
What's a trip to Philly without a visit to the rivals on Passyunk? 

Before I start, I want to mention that I'm from Arizona, and before coming to Philly, I have never had a cheesesteak before in my life. I'm not a huge fan of steak/roast beef/red meat sandwiches, so essentially I never really got around to trying an authentic cheesesteak (and being from Phoenix, a mediocre one at that). But I decided, When in Rome, and saved my first ever cheesesteak experiences for my first ever trip to Philly. 

Me being me, I had to try a steak from both Pat's and Geno's to compare. From all the people I survey, the favor between Pat's and Geno's is a pretty stark 50/50. So how could I try one without the other? Answer: I can't. Our first steak was from Geno's, and it was pretty good. However, I enjoyed the steak from Pat's significantly more. 

Two things about our steak from Pat's that stood out: the steak itself and the Wiz. The steak is cut differently at both places, and I'm assuming seasoned differently too. Pat's steaks seemed much heartier, with a more genuine and robust flavor than that of their neighbor. I also appreciated how the Wiz was served piping hot, and how we were given three generous lathers of Wiz on top of our delicious steak meat (this was more Wiz than what we got across the street, and seemed to be a better/appropriate steak to Wiz ratio). 

As every reviewer posts it is cash only, and expect to pay around $10 per person for a steak, drink and cheese fries/fries. Additionally, don't expect stellar service from the staff either. They get you in and they get you out. Other than that, you're not gonna get much more. But in an odd way, I liked the brief and short interaction with employees; a reflection of that rough around the edges Philly/East Coast charm that I was so unaccustomed to.

I'm sure there are much better cheesesteaks around, but for my first cheesesteak experience, I have to say I am impressed. Granted, we went for more of the tourist experience, but it was still enjoyable from a diner's standpoint.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: For tourists. LOTS of better steak sandwiches.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
... and here, I'm guessing, is how enemies are made.

Pat's-

I really wanted to like your steaks- no- I wanted to LOVE your steaks.

As someone who grew up in the Philadelphia metro area eating delicious gooey cheesesteaks from the likes of Real Pizza in Wayne, etc., I've been traveling the world for the last 13 years proselytizing our city's primary culinary export, bitching about airport restaurants that claim to offer "Philadelphia Cheesesteaks," and spreading the word about Amoroso's rolls to all who would listen.  I had never been to Pat's Steaks and, honestly, I thought I was just saving the best for last.

In San Francisco, I got my wife hooked on the Cheese Steak Shop on Divisidero, so when we got to Philly, we were both primed and ready to dive into Pat's (Geno's is not and will not be an option for us given their English-speaking only stance for their customers.  Call it racism or xenophobia, I call it just plain sad and mean-spirited, especially since they're adjacent to a Mexican food restaurant.  Aren't business owners supposed to be inclusive as a profit-maximizing strategy?  Anyway, back to the review).

So we fight our way down the sidewalk past the neon abomination known as Geno's and see Pat's looking as Philly as Philly can be.  We order at the steak window (no chicken cheesesteaks for the wife, it would seem), then head over to the soda and fries window (annoying rigmarole) to get birch beer (why hasn't this PA treat made it out of the state???).

I was so hungry I horked my steak down, but completely without relish.
In my mind, one of the things that makes a great cheesesteak is that all of the ingredients are jumbled up together because the chef has taken the time to chop it all together on the grill.  At Pat's, they take the roll, layer on the cheese (provolone, in my case), then put on the meat and finally top it off with grilled onions.

Separate but equal?  I think not.

The roll was huge, the steak ended up being pretty dry (since it wasn't slathered in gooey cheese), and the whole concoction just sort of slid, slowly, down my gullet like a fat, dry-meat watermelon.  Where was the flavor?

Sad.

Pat's.  We could have been so good together, but you're just not for me.  I'm leaving you for Jim's on South Street who, if I remember correctly, knows how to do gooey cheesesteaky goodness.

Disappointing.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Food is Great, service is ok..... they're just cheese steaks but "Whiz With" is the way to go... make sure you get those dried red chillis in oil and that hot sauce on it.. dont put too much or your stomach wont be happy w/you the next day!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: With wiz son. Def the best cheesesteak in the US of A. Have your money and order ready before you get to the front of the line. Prob the only place that I don't mind eating outside.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Not bad, but way overrated. Tasted like a typical diner cheesesteak from anywhere in the country. Rude workers, outdoor seating only.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I've been here twice, the first time to compare to Geno's and the second time to make sure I didn't just try them on an off day.  Turns out I'm still not a fan. The steak I had both times was super chewy, kind of dry and just not very appetizing IMO.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Overpriced and absolutely nothing special about it. Food tasted bland, fries are the cost of another meal. They charge what they do because it was on TV..don't waste your time.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
filthy (fil'the) pronunciation
adj., -ier, -iest.

   1. Covered or smeared with filth; disgustingly dirty. See synonyms at dirty.
   2. Obscene; scatological.
   3. Vile; nasty: a filthy traitor.
   4. Great culinary creations consisting of an abundance of grease, fat, and what is sometimes referred to as "love."
   5. Anything with cheese whiz on it.
   6. A "whiz-wit" at Pat's

filthily filth'ily adv.
filthiness filth'iness n. 

-------------------------------------

Every time I come to Philly, I visit Pat's.  Now you think the 'Soup Nazi' was bad, the guys here are much worse....but in a good way.  It's pretty basic....you say "whiz-wit" for a steak sandwich with onions, or just plain "whiz" or "whiz-wit-out" for a steak sandwich without onions.  Order up, pay, step aside, and if you want, get some fries.  I think all the goodness from this places comes from this place comes from the fact they haven't cleaned their griddle since they have opened creating an insanely aromatic and potent "flavor zone."  

Next time you are in Philly, visit Pat's, follow my ordering instructions, and enjoy.  Geno's, across the street, makes a different kind of sandwich, and is much more sanitary, but side by side comparison has Pat's winning hand's down.  I will review Geno's shortly because there are some good points there.  Go to Pat's first, trust me.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Overrated in my opinion, but you have to try it at least once. I completed a taste test of Pat's vs. Geno's side by side and Pat's wins my vote; however, you are better off at Jim's or Dalessandro's (in Roxborough).
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: We got recommended to try Pats by a couple of our friends for an authentic Philly Cheesesteak. I guess thanks to Papal visit, there was absolutely no line when we got there! Woo-hoo! We ordered the cheesesteak with mushrooms and onion (whiz wit) for our flight. It was pretty good and quite different from the regular cheesesteak sandwich we had back at home in OC. The beef was fully loaded. They're a bit dried, wish we asked for more cheese. Overall, we were glad we tried out the true Philly cheesesteak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: WARNING: if you have any dietary restrictions do NOT go here. Management is super unaccommodating. The person I was with was yelled at by the manager for ordering a vegetarian option steak and called a "hipster". Buddy, your shop is on East Passyunk - figure it out. If you want a bland steak and horrible service this is your place. Also, remember, cash only so stick your ATM card in one of the very sketchy places near by.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Service was quick, factory line like.  Line long but was expected for a popular spot.  Smelled of old oil outside in the air.  I did the "one wit whiz" and the whiz was downright nasty.  It seemed like the concept of toasted crusty bread with sizzled steak, grilled onions and cheese has been commercialized and converted to fast food much to the dismemberment of a traditionally great hoagie/sandwich.  Next time I'll order it from a sit down restaurant and order it with provolone or American and skip the liquid velveeta cheese.  Price was $19 for the sandwich, soda and fries.  Not unreasonable.  The condiments outside looked a bit sketchy and unattended.  Trash cans around had a putrid foul odor like urine/rottenness.  Prob should be cleaned and emptied more often.  Positives, I found a parking spot super close and without much hassle.  Fries, soda were fine.  Service fast, efficient.  Though staff seem like robots.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Eh. We decided to try Pat's first, then Geno's. Pat's was not wrapped up, and unbeknowst to me, grease was dripping like free-flowing water off the side of my steak, and totally ruined a brand-new shirt. But this review will not be tainted by that. Pat's just isn't as good as Geno's. Although I will have to say there's not a HUGE difference between the two. I had the Provolone, without onions. For all you purists, I did try my husband's, which was Wit, Wiz. The provolone was ice cold, and the steak just wasn't all that great. The ordering process is way too fast and they're nicer at Geno's. Sorry Pat's!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Philadelphia is unique. Similar to NYC in the amount of locations you can go to where service is "Fuck You,  Pay Me!" Pat's is similar to this. It is a tourist site. I went while visiting Philly and grabbed both a cheesesteak sandwich from Pat's and Geno's. Amazing! Delicious! Not the Best But better then Geno's. I enjoyed it so much I wanted to get another but without the cheese and the guy was a complete asshole about it. You would think I was asking him for a free sandwich with his fucking attitude but whatever. Cheesesteak sandwiches are far superior to the ones over at Geno's. As I have said before I can forgive shit service when the food is good.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
We were debating between Geno's and Pat's but chose pat's because it had more reviews. We waited in line and from the time we got our food was about 20 mins later and this was at lunch time on a weekday.

The meat I thought was a bit dry and overall the experience was a bit rubbery. If you like the texture of condoms I guess this is the perfect experience for you. The upside is that the pepper were delicious but this wasn't the major reason why we came here. You're probably better off finding a hole in the wall with a shorter wait time and a decent cheese steak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Got the sandwich with provolone and added peppers. It was okay the fries were good. Bring cash as they do not take plastic. One line is for sandwiches and another for everything else. Nice to say I did it but won't go out of my way.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I guess I never reviewed Pat's....

Something about this place has a certain charm. Growing up I remember Rocky getting a cheeseteak at Pat's, then his old boss told him to put out a cigarette because he was in training.

The people that work here are jerks and will make fun of you if you order a cheesesteak hoagie. Even though its on the menu. God forbid you want lettuce and tomato on a cheesesteak. They also break your stones if you don't use the exact specifics to order your sandwich. Dude you work at a freaking cheesesteak joint, Its not hard to make a cheesesteak. Why make it hard on me. I'm just trying to get some grub. Seriously.

With that said the Cheesteaks here....I'm always satisfied.  But you can probably get a better cheesesteak somewhere else. I just come here every so often for the novelty of this place.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I really cant comment on the food.  It was the first time for me in Philly and I wanted cheesesteak.  The lines were so long. Around the building and down the block.  I was sad I couldnt try it because I didnt have the time to wait. so my suggestion is to leave enough time to wait in the darn line!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Service was quick and the line was short. I ordered mushroom pizza steak. I think it was good but not the level of 4 stars, might be 3.5.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
"Did you get me my Cheez Wiz, boy?" -- The Blues Brothers (1980)

Wit or wit-out?  This is the language you need to understand before you go to Pat's.  This means onions and whiz if you don't know.  Now, people will tell you that Whiz is the way to go and if it is your first time, you gotta try it with the Whiz.  Just to do it once.

So here is the deal - after you specify your onion preference (why would you get it wit-out?) and your cheese preference (you can also get Provolone, American or a Pizza Steak), then you need your cash.  These guys don't take plastic.  And the first window will only take your steak order, so if you want a drink and/or fries, you need to slide down to your left and order those separately.  But these guys move FAST.

I ordered a mushroom and pepper steak wit (onions and whiz).  I got a Dr. Pepper and no fries.  It was 9:30pm and I had just flown in from Atlanta and my traveling companion texted me when we landed and said "where are we going for cheesesteaks?"  So obviously, I Yelped it.

The cheesesteak is really big, but OH so good.  They shove a plastic fork in the top for you and you will probably need it.  We enjoyed our steaks as we ate al fresco (your only choice) and drank our sodas.  The steak was thicker cut then expected and a little on the tough side (not cut properly), so as much as I loved the experience and the flavor, the meat quality left a lot to be desired.  Based on the beef and how it was cut, I had to knock this to 3 stars.

I'm definitely hitting up the competitor down the street on my next trip to compare.  I only wish I had the time on this trip.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
We fell into this tourist trap, like so many others do!

We decided to try a cheesesteak and cheese fries from both Pat's and Geno's to make a determination which was best.  

All four people in our group agreed that Pat's was best.  We came through on a Monday afternoon and neither was very busy.  

I will say that the employees at both restaurants were flat out rude, which was surprising for such touristy places.  The employees at Pat's were a little more pleasant than Geno's, but neither were even close to appropriate.  Also parking is near impossible to find close by.  We got lucky and we're still about 4-5 blocks away.

After speaking to locals, when we come back to Philly we will go elsewhere for an "authentic" Philly Cheesesteak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Second day of our Cheesesteak tour and we hit our first stop of the day, Pat's. This time we tried it with onions and provolone and it was quite tasty but not the best we have had. Service was super quick and there was no line, but the bread and meat were not as flavorful and the provolone was a bit dull. The onions were super tasty though and were the best part. Still a great option for a cheesesteak in Philly tho and I would definitely recommend!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Updating my review from 7 years ago. Still go to pats every once in a while. Most recent trip it was pretty bad. Still better than the other place, but you can go to pretty much any corner store and get a better product. After living in philly for so long, I can not say this place counts as 5 stars anymore.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I like the cheesesteaks here, but I hear they aren't the best, but I don't have much to compare it to because I don't go to Philadelphia often enough to venture out to the non-touristy cheesesteak joints.  I promise I will next time.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
My family and I went on a Philly Cheesesteak tpur. We saved what we thought would be the three best places for last: Tony Luke's, Pat's and Geno's. We were very disappointed.  Customer service was nill. It was very clear that their goal was to kick out the sandwiches as fast as they could with no regard for quality. At Pat's, we didn't even get the sandwich we ordered and the meat was tough.  At  Geno's,  the cheese wasn't melted and our fried onions were pretty much raw. At T.L. we nicknamed our sandwich  'slim' because of the lack of meat in it. 
At the end of our tour, which also had us visiting Chubby's, Delassandros and Barry's in Roxbourough and Cleavers in Rittenhouse Square, we picked Barry's and Cleavers as our top two.  Packed sandwiches, tender meat, cheese mixed throughout, sautéed onions and peppers to perfection and rolls were the perfect degree of chewy.  Customer service was friendly.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
wow i'm surprised this place doesn't have more good reviews! I am a first time visitor to Philly, and it was actually my first time I've ever had an authentic Philly cheesesteak and I thought it was DELICIOUS! I really thought this was a go-to place for locals, because it was very busy and the atmosphere just seemed like the place to go to! The price is very expensive in my opinion though but then again, i don't really have anything to compare it to. I liked all the difference choices you can get, and i thought fries were really good. They are very huge though, so I would recommend you half it with someone like i did :)

Across the street is Geno's, which I was way too full to try after coming from Pat's, but my friends and I ventured over there so that the big boys of our group could try one and compare the two places back-to-back. All of them said that Geno's was good, but Pat's was definitely better.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Pats Steaks is legengary but for the price it just serves as a tourist trap for people who live outside philly. You can get better service, better steak, and better prices at places like Jim's Steaks on South Street or at Steve's Steaks. I just think they are overated, but still better than Geno's
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Nothing to rave about and honestly the people that work here are rude. It's just a line to take your money. The food wasn't anything to go ga ga over. I honestly thought it was average. Would I come back- nahhhhh
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: In my humble opinion, tied with Jim's for the best cheesesteak in town... And one huge perk, fast lines!  At other popular cheesesteak joints you are in for up to a 45 minute wait... No here!  The steak is delicious and the rolls are fresh.  My favorite is a cheesesteak with American, without onions add mushrooms... Delicious!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: If this is the best of Philly then Philly don't got it down. Its true ...its just hyped up. I've had better Philly cheessteaks NOT in Philly. But a friend of mine said there r others in Philly that r way better. The steak at pats is mass produced. Its Wayyy over priced and overrated.  I'd rather go to a ma n pa shop down the road where they take their time to perfect an authentic Philly cheesesteak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I was in philly for only a few hours and my friends who went to UPenn said I had to do the Pat's vs Geno's taste test for philly cheese steaks. I don't know if I had higher expectations for cheesetakes, but both of them were extremely mediocre. It needed sauce or something, because had very little flavor. It wasn't BAD, but just wasn't good. I'm sure there are better cheesesteak places around Philly.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Great place for a cheese steak though overpriced and usually a long line to wait in.  Parking sucks too.  Though the wait is worth it.  I usually bounce between there and Geno's across the street.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Don't bother.  Go down a few block's so Cosmi's

Pat's is nasty, greasy, and don't give you a lot of value for your dollar (read: little meat). Also, the sweaty guys slopping the meat onto the girl really don't do it for me
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Fair cheesesteak at best. Kind of tasteless. Staff can be rude. Not a big fan of this place or Geno's. I guess they get a point for being open 24h, as this would probably be great drunk food at 3 in the morning when you don't really care what you're eating.
They seem to be geared toward giving visitors what they see as a traditional "Philly" experience more than serving a quality version of Philadelphia's signature sandwich. 
If you want a truly good cheesesteak, there are countless other places in the city that are head and shoulders above this place. Tony Luke's comes to mind right off the top of my head. 
If you want a crappy steak, but want some selfies in front of one of one of the most famous cheesesteak places in the city (famous for what? I don't know... lousy food? I guess...) then by all means, stop on by. If you want a true cheesesteak that has taste, then go somewhere else, but be sure to drive by Pat's and Geno's on your way, so you can get some pictures to show your friends back home, just don't bother with the food.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Those who get stuck at Jim's or elsewhere are just too lazy to come to P Square for the real thing.

Pat's is devoid of flash glitz and advertising glamor that Geno's needs to get patrons. Pat's is simple and classic. Don't try to fix a good thing.

These steaks are juicy/greasy and perfectly melty with Whiz. Oninos and mushrooms are sauteed. These people really care about their steak, just not you.

UPDATE: WTF happened here? Did someone sell the company? A recent visit with out of towners produced a fatty steak-stuffed sandwich. We're talking huge amounts of fat in everyone's sandwich. The meat tasted less.....good. And a conversation with my neighbors fortified the fact that we all think Pat's doesn't taste good anymore. Did they get worse or have all our palates suddenly become spoiled foodies?
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Pat's came in second in my books, it was enjoyable and good. Service was quick and the cheesesteak looked so dam sexy!

The bread was soft, filled with a lot of steak along with onions and a slab of cheese wiz on top. Appearance-wise, it was the most sexiest cheesesteak I've ever seen in my life. Taste-wise, it was just good. I loved how much steak there was but it was a tad bit on the dry side. It's good to try Pat's once to say that you did and to judge it yourself.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I came here with my fiancé and best friend after the phillies game. Right across from it was Geno's. I looked up both on Yelp and Pat's had better reviews so we chose to go with the rest of the foodie crowd. Service is fast. you place your order and in less than a minute and you get your sandwich in less than 20 seconds. I ordered the Philly steak with onions, mushrooms, and whiz. It was the best cheesesteak I have ever had. Before this cheesesteak I can honestly say I never understood the craze. The sandwich was perfect. My fiancé enjoyed his too. He ordered the peppersteak with onions and provolone. 

The only downside to the experience has nothing to do with the food. Parking around this area is tough. Just a little FYI for those driving out here.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Pat's is terrific. And, as a bonus, they aren't racist assholes like the fuckers at Geno's.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Looks kind of trashy but cheesesteak is amazing!!!!! So glad I tried this before I left Philly!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Overrated tourist trap.  Cold, stale bread, unevenly cooked meat and very little flavor.

No comparison to the real best cheesesteaks in Philly...go to Jim's on South Street or Chink's instead...those are the real cheesesteak champions.

Also disturbed by the vaguely racist statements posted on the windows there.  Won't be back.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Great place to get some food late at night great staff just make sure you have cash no cards cash only
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
It's quite a sight on Passyunk it's congested with cars and people trying to find parking. I checked the websites of the two famous cheesesteaks I thought Pat's was more interesting and had choices of cheeses but when I ordered the cheesesteak I was trying my best to avoid the cheesewhiz, not particularly appetizing I was surprised they didnt give you a choice. Yuck! If you cannot even understand the names of food additives it's best to avoid it altogether. The mushrooms and peppers added flavors but it was soaking through at every bite. The steak was tasty but had too much fat. Here's my breakdown:

Likes:
Soft and toasted bread
Mushrooms and peppers
Cherry peppers

Dislikes:
Cheesewhiz
Steak
Juice running down my hands and legs (metal tables with holes that go through)
Service - not friendly
Surrounding of the store was sparse and lacking in cleanliness
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I don't get the the whole obsession over Philly cheese steaks.  I have eaten at almost all of the top places and I dont get it. Pats is definitely the best, but that's not saying much. Its steakums with cheese wiz. I can get the same thing at the local pizza joint around the block from my house.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I did a taste test with Pat's and Geno's, back to back. Yes, I ate one of each. Both had cheese wiz and onions. I prefer the chopped meat at Pat's. Yummy stuff!!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Pat's was the first real cheesesteak place I dined at in Philly. I recall my friend Craig taking me here. It seems to be the most famous. Other friends of mine came into town not long ago and wanted to go to Pat's.

Pat's is good, but Geno's is across the street and it is a little better.

The Franklin Institute commissioned a video called Anthem that it used to show in its IMAX theatre. There was a sequence from Pat's in there.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Cold cheese and cold soggy bun. Didn't like Pat's. We went across the street to Geno's and love it! Geno's French roll really made the sandwich.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
PAT'S vs. geno's

I was sooo excited to FINALLY be in Philly for the first time because I wanted to try the Cheese Steaks. Being that I was only out there for 1 night I had to get one from each of the most well known spots, so that I could do the compare and contrast between the two.

I had heard so many times that Geno's was great and how many celebs go there and blah blah blah...and all I can say is FAIL!!!!!!

The sandwich was dry, the meat had no flavor and the onions were so raw that I had that annoying onion taste in my mouth for a while until I got back to the hotel and brushed my teeth...UGHHH...DON'T WASTE UR MONEY HERE...I've tasted better in NYC...don't be fooled by the celeb hype and the BRIGHT lights...

Then, I quickly made my way across the street. I order one from Pat's and I could tell just by watching them make it that it as going to taste WAY BETTER. The Bread was soft, the steak chopped up and JUICY, the onions and peppers COOKED and the cheese was regular American cheese, but good non the less...

LADIES AND GENTS WE HAVE A WINNER...PAT'S HANDS DOWN...
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Staff was rude and sandwich was pretty tasteless. Had Geno's couple nights before and far better experience. Go to Geno's.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Chopped steak, way better than Geno's, good portion
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I prefer chopped to shaved so I tried Pat's over Geno's.  It was disgusting either way.  I would suggest you try Pudge's in Blue Bell for a great steak with not soggy fries.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I hate to say it, but I'm going to... I think I'm a Geno's girl! 

We went to Pat's on our way back from 2 street on New Year's day. Considering we had been drinking for just about 24 hours straight, it was clear a cheesesteak was in order. 

Pat's was the first neon light we saw and we got in line (which was shorter than Geno's). We were craving the greasy disgusting meat and whiz spectacle that are Philly Cheesesteaks, but instead it was dry(ish). I want my roll dripping with whiz, and it just didn't happen. Super disappointing since I only get a cheesesteak once a year (strictly due to the fact I could eat them every single day- must set limits!). The hot cherry peppers were pretty good though- so points for that, Pats!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
First of all, I find it amazing that 2 places would stir passions like Pat's and Geno's does.  We were a group of 5 and divided on our favorite.

I had Steak, Whiz, Without.  I personally did not order so I don't have a problem with the ordering process. I did..LOVE it though. 

While we were leaving some kid on a bike yelled out PATS SUCKS! Which adds to my first paragraph..would there be such hatred if Geno's didn't exist? :)
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Donkeys in Camden is so much better then these steaks. Over priced and a waste of time to drive there
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Sandwich was good, but I was not wowed. Their onions were plentiful, and the bread was hearty, Found service to be rude, though, so knocking them down a star.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
It's Pat's need I say more? Everyone should experience Pats steaks especially at midnight after a Phillies game. The whole vibe of the neighborhood is unbeatable and the sandwiches are exactly how they should be!!! Delicious!!!!

The quality of the meat they use is what does it and they load the sandwiches up as well.

Get in line, don't screw up your order and enjoy!!!

I need to add that the peppers they have there are a favorite!!!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Loved the cheese steak and liked the bread. The meat was perfectly juicy! Wasn't able to try Geno's so can't compare.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Of course you go for the history and the location.  Trying to order like a local by doing your "wid" or "widout".  Standing around the crappy tables.  Watching the bus loads of tourists and locals show up.  Everyone having a good time just being there.  That is all part of the fun.  Not the world's greatest cheesesteak, but they are delicious!  Meat just needed a drop more salt to give it that flavor boost.  Thoroughly enjoyed it.  Have been here pretty much every time I visit Philadelphia.  If anything I liked it more recently.  I'm a provolone "wid" onion guy; can't handle eating Cheeze Whiz in any form.  Fries were also pretty good, too.  I'd give it 3-3.5 stars just for food, but clearly a 4 when you throw in the one-of-a-kind experience.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Not as good as it used to be, It has become more of a tourist attraction.  Still better than Genos
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Tourist trap but better than Geno's and has better quality food than them as well.
Pat's has always been there in a bind after the 2am drink up... but there are waaay better steaks out there.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
This was an interesting experience. 

Pat's and Geno's were right across from each other. So here is my take. 

Parking is non-existent at either locations. Seating is located outdoors and around the stores. There are lines at both stores too. So I was confused. Which one do I choose. So I did what most people seem to be doing. Get one from each!

Pat's lines move fast. These guys know what they are doing. You go up to the register and place your sandwich order and pick it up within a minute. No joke!  I ordered 3 subs and got them in under a minute. You pay cash. Then you move down the line and order your drink and fries. You pay cash here too. 

I ordered a mushroom cheesesteak with onions. My hubby ordered a plain cheesesteak with cheese wiz. The steak was sliced thinly. They give a lot. The sub was well seasoned, juicy and disappeared in record time. Their fries were crispy. 

Geno's cheesesteak was good too. The difference we noticed - steak was sliced a little thicker, about the same quantity of steak, less seasoning (not salty), and very little cheese (it was smeared onto one side of the bun).  It was delicious but a bit drier than Pat's. 

All in all it was a great taste comparison. We were stuffed!  Depending on your preference there is a sandwich for you on either side of the street. 

Geno's had an awesome DJ playing music to keep the folks lined up entertained. You can hear it loud and clear from Pat's. :-)

Experience the difference!!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: The sad reality of cheesesteaks is most of what makes one good is the bread, not the meat or cheese. While I enjoy pat's (I think the meat is better), I have to go with genos for the better bread. I enjoy John's Roast pork better than both, but if you want the true tourist experience (albeit near no discernible night life), this is where to go.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Of course I had to stop by Pat's, during my stop in Philly on my east coast road trip. Pat's is considered the first Philly cheese steak spot in history, so my expectations were high. The line was long when I arrived, but I took my place and patiently waited, as I drooled over the smells in the air. When I finally made it to the front I ordered a classic Cheese Steak, with cheese whiz, green peppers, onions, and mayo. The cheese steak was one of the better Phillies I've had in my lifetime, and definitely better than Geno's from across the street. My friend got a Philly from there, so we could compare the two, and simultaneously engorge on our Philly cravings. The biggest difference was how they prepared their steak. Pat's has thinly sliced steak which was grilled, vs Geno's which did thicker strips of steak. I'm definitely a bigger fan of thin steak on my phillys.Pat's is definitely a great spot to stop by for a cheese steak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I was so excited to try this place!
First time visiting philly and trying the original philly cheese steak!
But I guess I had too much excitement because it wasn't anything special.

However! the jalapeño they had on the condiment section was.. AMAZING.
So spicy and sour and sweet all at the same time. I know it sounds ridiculous but I might go back just for that. the pepper made the sandwich so much better than it is. 

And I think it's a bit overpriced for the amount of steak & cheese they give...
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Excellent Cheesesteak sandwich! I got the mushrooms, onions, pepper cheesesteak. It was so delicious!!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks
