categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
As any other Philly first timer I had to stop and grab one of the original cheesesteaks at Pat's during my summer X-country roadtrip http://KananAcrossAmerica.blogspot.com.  

The Verdict: Love the authentic experience, the lady taking my order even had that 'hurry up, I'm watching a Phillies game' attitude that I found comical, however the steaks ain't all that.  I mean I devoured it because it was my only meal of the day, but their at best 'okay.'

I highly recommend if its your first time in Philly, but I wouldn't go back.  WARNING: Cash Only!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: 3rd visit to Pat's in as many years. We ( my wife and I ) drive down to Philadelphia every once in a while from Central New Jersey . I know there are probably better cheesesteak places in Philly but I like Pat's because of its history. All in all the cheesesteak is good and I have no complaints . It taste even better when I happened to be there after a Flyers game . I personally didn't attend game but the fans added a Philly ambience. After all what could be better a nice day a Flyers win and a good cheesesteak. My wife likes Jim's steaks on South Street
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Some people will look at my star rating and wonder HOW IN THE WORLD DID I GIVE A 3! Well its my opinion of what I ate. So I will say we bought 1 sub from Pats and 1 sub from Genos (I'm going to post about them next) and we split them so we could both have some of each. Pat's sub was moist actually so much that the juices ran down my arm . My problem really is that they do not add tomato or lettuce or mayo to the subs and it wasn't really seasoned. They do provide salt, pepper and oregano at the window for you to add on your own. The cost was 10.50 for a whole sub which is the only way you can order it. With all that being said if I had to eat from there again I would but I would know to bring condiments.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: After hearing about this place for years, I wanted to check it out.  I've got to say that this was one of the more disappointing experiences I've ever had.  The sandwich was cold, bread was stale and worst of all, the meat had no flavor.  I'm from Chicago, and I'll take an Italian Beef any  day of the week over this mess at Pat's.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Let me resolve an age old Philadelphian dispute: Pat's Cheesesteaks are better than Gino's Cheesesteaks. I know this through no empirical evidence nor intellectual enterprise. In fact, I have never once tried a Gino's Cheesesteak, but I have been raised on the principle that the Irish know far more about how to slop red meat and cheese whiz on fresh bread than the Italians do. 

I believe Pat's is better than Gino's because Father Chuck told me it was true, and Father Chuck, at the time, was the finest man I had ever met. And like the Catholic upbringing that introduced me to 12 years of Parochial schooling, faith in Pat's is better left untested. So here's a story that might raise a few eyebrows: a young and handsome Catholic priest decides to reward some high school kids for volunteering at a soup kitchen, packs the little angels into the back of his mini van, and begins speeding down the Schuykill Expressway to an almost abandoned looking spot in Southeast Philly save for two long lines of zombies waiting for their fix of the good stuff. The children are then subjected to a flurry of curse words, grill-burnt hands, dead animals, and a meal that's so damned greasy and filling, they'll soon find themselves unconscious for the entirety of the car ride back home. 

This all as a result of Father asking us if we've ever had a Philadelphia cheesesteak. When the answer was a unilateral no, he feigned offense. "May the Lord forgive your neglectful parents." He then set forth some ground rules, I still live by:

1. Beware the Philadelphia Cheesesteak moniker: if you're in Philadelphia and you're eating a cheesesteak, the odds are it will be good. If you're at a place in the suburbs or another state that serves "Philadelphia cheesesteaks", it is a lie deserving of a flipped table in the hall of the Pharisees.

2. You can get all kinds of fancy and wonderful cheesesteaks in the city, but if you're at Pat's, you go traditional and get the whiz. It's gross, of course, but tradition is tradition. If we can handle transubstantiation each Sunday, I think we can handle a little whiz.

3. Finally, as we already determined: Pat's is better than Gino's. No reason. Just canonical truth. 

Father Chuck proved to not only a good priest in a world full of monsters, he was the best of all role models. During my high school years, Father taught me how to swear in three languages, drive like an absolute maniac, and to believe that good deeds really do matter to God. Above all else, Father Chuck taught us to memorize our cheesesteak order before walking up to the counter or risk a brutal verbal assault from the staff behind the counter.   

The ephemeral Catholic Church of Father Chuck's world was one where giving back was cool. Father Chuck was cool, so serving the homeless at a soup kitchen and playing piano at a children's hospital was most certainly cool. I truly loved the man and the life he seemed to live. I think Father Chuck could tell that and finally sat me down and asked if I had considered the priesthood. After a few hours discussing more about the vocation, I took his advice and spent a weekend at Saint Charles Borromeo Seminary. As an awkward teen already living a life of forced celibacy, the priesthood didn't seem so bad. Sure, you'd have to wear itchy clothes and say a lot of masses, but you could always pack up and head down to Philly and eat that incredibly flavorful steak on freshly baked bread.

As you can probably tell by my other reviews filled with incessant swearing and talks of orgies, poop, and violence, I did not become a priest. I also only went back to Pat's Steaks on one other occasion. I was with my then friend, Kaitlyn. All was going well until Kaitlyn brought along a blind date to tag along with us to Pat's. To my memory, the young man was awkward and sweet, though I can't for the life of me remember his name. What I do remember is the poor bastard stuttered his order and was immediately called a "fucking moron," by two of the grill cooks hoping to move the line. I of course came prepared and had my order memorized, and Kaitlyn and I were married five years later. So what's the message here? Go to Pat's Steaks, and trust your heroes when they say they can lead you on a path towards a lifelong vocation. Perhaps some day they will.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
My 2nd favorite Cheesesteak next to Steve's Prince of Steaks

CHEESESTEAK RATING: A-

They use a chopped steak and plenty of it. A good amount of grease but not to much and a good wiz.

Touristy like Geno's but really good!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Maybe it's just me, but Pat's and Geno's rank the same for me. In fact, I believe everything is the same and they are only fooling us ;).

Cheeseteaks - Whiz is most classic popular, but I'd lean towards American if they have it. The line moves along very quickly so don't fret, young grasshopper.

To satisfy your cheesesteak craving, Pat's will get it done. But if you have checked off Pat's from your list then there are tons more places to try in Philly... spread the love!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
It's not my first time coming here. The famous dueling cheesesteak joints in Philly. Yes this here is the better of the two as far as I'm concerned. We tried both steaks years ago the first time I came here, and yes,, Pat's is the better of the two.

Located in the middle of a residential neighborhood, Pat's is the unassuming little humble spot. It doesn't have the flair of the other guy, BUT if you take a closer look, the line is a LOT longer here than there. The reason for this is not brand loyalty, but real honest to goodness good ass cheesesteak. Once you're in the premises, you'll see all the pictures of the celebrities and sports teams all over the walls and vaulted ceiling. This shops tells the story that it's stood the time as one of the legendary cheesesteak shops in all of Philly.

I'd definitely come back,, and will tell people about this famous dueling cheesesteak joints here in Philly. I'll even tell them that this spot is the better of the two.

Life is too short, get up off your couch and experience it first hand.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
This is my first Philadelphia review and what a better way to start by reviewing a place that serves the icon of Philadelphia food culture: The Philadelphia Cheesesteak. I went to this place with a friend from Cherry Hill, New Jersey a while ago, and he said to me that this is something that every tourist to Philadelphia should experience, and it was recommended by another friend who is originally from Ambler. This is the first cheesesteak place I have been to in Philadelphia. While I would not visit this place often if I was ever a resident of this interesting city, I found the Cheesesteak here to be tastily adequate.

I ordered a Cheesesteak with Cheez Whiz as the cheese, which is a processed cheese sauce. My friend got the same thing, and we shared a cup of fries. The steak itself was chopped up bits of meat, probably would have tasted really mediocre if it was not for the Cheez Whiz which made it tastier. I found the bread probably a few steps above mediocre. I thought it was a tad dry, but the grease from the beef made the bread really soft, chewy and flavorful. 

As for the fries, they were pretty tasty with the right amount of salt, and the texture had the right amount of crisp that made the fries almost addicting to eat. 

Despite eating a somewhat tasty cheesesteak, I think it is a little pricey, since I paid almost $8 for the cheesesteak. Fries are almost $3. I think it's because this place has got so famous that it is slowly becoming really touristy. Service is extremely effective. As long as you read the rules sign while you stand in line, you can get your food in a few minutes after you order. Since we were eating on the tables outside, a few flies came in and irritated us, so they definitely need to figure out a way to prevent insects from coming in. A great advantage is that this place is open 24 hours so it is not a bad choice for food after a night out in the city.

Overall, this is not a bad place to get a somewhat tasty cheesesteak and fries. I know that there are better cheesesteak places in this interesting city, and I am still in the hunt for best Cheesesteak in Philly.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Stops #3 and 4 of a cheesesteak tour I took with a couple buddies last weekend.  Gotta do the Pat's vs. Geno's challenge (a brilliant marketing strategy, I might add...who cares who wins, they BOTH get the business!)

Anyway, the whole cheesesteak thing started with Pat's in the 1930's, so we included the comparison on our trip, thinking of Pat's as our baseline.

First of all, it's an assembly line...took us about 30 seconds to get a sandwich in a crowded city block.  Roll, meat, fried onions, whiz, wrap and done.  Seemed kinda institutional.

However, the taste was better than expected.  We were warned that there are better tasting steaks in town, which is true, but this "touristy" experience was still pretty good.  The meat was seasoned well, the roll was nicely chewy and the whiz just tied it all together.  But much like the Anchor Bar in Buffalo (originator of buffalo wings), there have been improvements to the original.  But Pat's is still a nice experience, placing #6 out of our eight stops (behind Sonny's, Tony Luke's, Campo's, John's Roast Pork and Jim's Steaks.)
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I got a "provolone with" and it was disappointing the meat needed salt and pepper to enhance the meat flavor. The grilled onions were yummy.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: 3.5 stars. This is basically just expensive junk food. Kind of like doritos in steak form. It's good, I enjoyed it. But this isn't exactly a food destination in terms of quality or pricing. In my measure Geno's willingness to go the extra inch toward junky-ness put it a notch above Pat's, which was equally as junk-foody but with pretension to being better quality.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Extremely disappointed. The only reason i gave it another star was that its across the street competitor Geno's was worse.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Wanted to try the original cheesesteaks so I went to both Pat's and Geno's. The only difference was I got Whiz at Pat's and provolone at Geno's. Overall, they're both about the same though it seemed like the bread was better at Pat's. Overall I give the nod to Pat's but honestly, you can get better cheesesteak than you'll find at either one. 

It was amusing to hear the people who didn't know how to order getting scolded.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Pretty cheap and delicious cheese steaks! I'll come here during next visit in Phily, cause the food's worth it.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
A day trip calls for a Philly Cheese Steak quest! Last stop: Pat's King of Steaks. 

I'm not sure why Pat's King of Steaks has so much hype against Geno's Steaks. We tried the Philly Cheese Steak Whiz with grilled peppers and grilled onions. The only thing I like about this cheese steak is their whiz. The rest didn't taste good. The meat was sliced and it didn't have much flavor. The bread was tough to eat as well, as if the bread was sitting out for a while.

There was a long time to order, but make sure you know what to order when it's your turn. The line goes fairly fast and the people are quick to make your cheese steak. Pat's King of Steaks also accepts cash, which makes the ordering faster. I forgot to mention, but there are 2 separate windows: one to order cheese steaks while the other window is for sides and drinks. 

I was disappointed in this place just like Geno's Steaks. Rivals? More like relatives that's for sure. I couldn't find any difference between the 2, besides their whiz maybe?

I can give this place another try when I come back up to Philly to visit.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: On a short trip to Philly, my dad and I had to go settle the great debate once and for all: Pat's or Geno's. We walked up to the window, nervous about ordering wrong, when one of the old time regulars helped us through the process all while entertaining my three year old by making his nose squeak. We found a table and split out sandwich. The steak was deliciously seasoned, juicy, and tender. The gooey cheese complimented it perfectly while it ran down my chin. We cleaned up, thanked the owners who were outside doing an Uber Eats photo shoot, and went across the street. The entertaining regular told us not to waste our money, in jest, of course. He was right. After consuming a lesser cheesesteak we walked back over to head to the car, told them by unanimous vote they won, and spent a few minutes talking to the owners again. They came out with a t-shirt for my son. Overall, the food was amazing and the experience was an absolute blast. Now that I'm back in Indy I'm craving another sandwich.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: This place still has the best cheese steaks in philly other then geno's with either one you can't go wrong peroid!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Came to Pat's a day after experiencing Geno's, and I think Pat's sandwich was slightly better. The flavor of the meat better, but Geno's cheese sauce takes this one.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
cheesesteak with onions and chiz whiz! WAAA WAAA WEE WA!

After an hour drive from Atlantic City we decided to head to the city of brotherly love for lunch and it was worth the trip! I was salivating for the famous cheesesteak on the drive there. Although it was over 90 degrees and the line was overflowing to the streets (thankfully no one got hit by a car in the process of waiting) I didnt mind getting a little tan in the process. If you turn 180 degrees the competition (GENO'S) was just across the street and they had pretty much the same amount of customers overflowing to the streets.

Originally our plan was to order at Pat's then head to Geno's for a comparison but after one cheesesteak at Pat's it was a wrap! GREAT FOOD! Who would have thought of cheese whiz? Now it got me thinking what other savory meals i can cook up and put cheese whiz on top.

yes, yes and more yes to Pat's!!! Thanks Philly for the love.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
EXTREMELY OVER RATED!  One reason we drove all the way from Washington DC is to try out this place and the other 'famous' cheese steak place right across.  My personal opinion is that both places doesn't deserve higher that one star.
Food:  1/5.  Extremely bland and no flavor at all.  I honestly believe that this, and the other place,  are the worst place that I have eaten a cheese steak sandwich.
Price:  1/5.  For the quality of the food, extremely not worth it.
Overall, it was a disappointing experience.  We were thinking that we would end up deciding which one serves a better cheese steak, this or the other one across.  It ended up we were deciding which one was worst.  Completely disappointing.  But of course, this is just my personal opinion.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: For my first ever cheesesteak, I'd say it was delicious. Didn't feel the hospitality ordering like I usually do in Georgia but overall, it's worth writing home about.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I'm sorry, but this place just did not live up to expectation.  Tony Luke's is the best beef.  This stuff tasted like Grade D meat with no flavor topped off with the nasty wiz sauce and some unimpressive and watery grilled onions.  It just wasn't good.  Look the place is a tourist trap.  There's lines around the damn block everyday.  With that type of assemply line operation it just ain't gonna be that good - and it wasn't.  In fact, it was a bad experience.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
There's a battle between who's better?!?!?!?! Really?!?!?!? Don't buy into the hype.

Pat's is better then Geno's hands down. There is no competition between the two...(meat has flavor, portion is bigger, the Wiz is Wiz like and isn't runny {I still don't get how Geno's wiz was runny?!?!}, you can add peppers and mushrooms, and the bread is better). 

With that said:
 
IF YOU DON'T LIVE WITHIN A FIVE MILE RADIUS do yourself a favor and go to your local supermarket. You will need to a buy a onion, a nice soft bakery sub roll, a bottle of cheese whiz and some steak 'umm (or shaved beef from the meat counter if available). Dice and sautee the onions and then cook the steak. Cut the bread. Heat the wiz. Spread the Wiz on the roll then add steak and onion. 

TaDa! You've just created a cheesesteak BETTER then both Geno's and Pat's!

If you must go then save the $9 bucks you'd spend at Geno's and buy two from Pat's!

(BTW I know there is also a debate over Wiz or Provolone. Go Wiz, the provolone adds little flavor)
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Although I've yet to try Jim's (supposedly the best of the three) or Geno's, I can reliably say that Pat's dishes out a fine cheesesteak. The line moves pretty quickly, the seating arrangement is plentiful and the vibe is chill. I'd suggest getting your cheesesteak "Wit" (i.e. with onions). They have birch beer and root beer too so that's kind of awesome tas well.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I had to check this place out since I've never had a "Philly cheese steak", and the rivalry between Pat's and Gino's was interesting, so our group checked it out. The line was long, but they were quick; I was so surprised my steak came out 4 seconds later! The fries are great because they're crunchy and soft. I'm sure there are other better cheese steak places, but you have to start broad to refine your taste :) 

Also finding a table was difficult, and it's hard to eat the sandwich sitting down since it's soggy and dripping everywhere. My suggestion is to have a friend scope out a table while one stays in line - the experience is much better when it's not dripping all over your clothes.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Try number two.
Melissa W,  such a pro. Orders, "whiz wit" Success. 

The sandwich here at least looks like a bit more thought was put behind it, it comes out looking a heck of a lot better than Genos. There is more meat,  more appetizing grilled onions. Softer bread. Taste wise, it could use some tang, like come jalapenos or something. 

I can't say its the best I've had still. But still a lot more appetizing than Genos. My vote for Philly Sandwiches still lies at Hershels

Sandwiches run about $8 each before adding all the extra toppings
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks

White red headed bro working the register  on the night side never gives enough cheese for the cheesesteak. Stop skimpin dawg. Don't make me even think about considering Genos. More cheez.

xx

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Over rated!!! Please do not waste your precious $11.50. While visiting Philadelphia, one of the must dos was trying a philly cheese steak! We tried Geno's and Pats, which seem to be pretty popular, one in front of the other. Very visible signs.  In our opinion, Pats was much better than Geno's. We bought their most  popular cheesesteaks which is basically  flavorless meat and whiz and we also order cheesesteak with mushroom. 
As a family of 5, we all came to the consensus that it's overrated. On the other hand Geno's fries were pretty good! 
Happy with Wawas cheesesteak!!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Had to try the famous Philly Cheesesteak from the big two of the Cheesesteak rivalry--Pat's and Geno's. Both were disappointing. Pat's is a little better though. Both remind me of "Steak-Ums," which I always thought were pretty good for a knock off Cheesesteak at home but not close to the real thing. Unfortunately I was wrong. These places probably actually use Steak-Ums. Pat's was pretty flavorless and not impressive at all. It's a better Cheesesteak than Geno's though. But, Pat's is dirtier than Geno's. How disappointing this was!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Ordered a mushroom cheesesteak wiz wit. Parking could be tricky unless you get lucky (parallel parking). The line moves fast and you better move with it or else get in the back of the line. Don't panic, you'll end up with a cheesesteak and it will be worth it. The cheesesteak are a little pricey but the flavor is FULL and the peppers you can eat on the side are AMAZING. I left full and happy to eat at the place Rocky chose to eat his cheesesteak.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I definitely like pats over Geno's any day but if you want the best cheesesteak in philly you have to go to delsandro or clevers. Pats and Geno's are more tourist location and are the most famous places but they're the the greatest in philly.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
While I've been to Philly a few times before and had cheesesteaks, this is the first time I've tried one from the two biggest names in the city.  I chose Pat's to try first as they're the older of the two.  Geno's, you're next. 
 
ATMOSPHERE:
We must've stepped on dog poop because we luckily found parking right across the street from the restaurant.  As we pulled in, I saw the line that spilled out onto the street.  I was thinking hell no, forget it.  But you know what?  The line moves pretty darn quick, so just do it!  Hordes of cars kept coming and coming with the line at Pat's and Geno's taking turns ebbing and flowing.  Everyone entertained themselves while waiting to get to the ordering window, especially in selfies with the neon biz sign.  Once you near the ordering window is when you'll see the menu and "how to order" signs.  The first window handles strictly sandwich orders.  If you want sides or drinks, you order and pay again at the second window.  Picnic table-style seating wraps around the fluorescent-lit covered lanai.  There are no restrooms or place to wash your hands.  Napkin dispensers are readily available to mop up the messy job at hand.
 
MENU:
Steak sandwiches in 13 varieties, roast pork, hot dog, fish cake, fries in 4 varieties.  Water, soda, coffee, tea, cocoa.
 
3-STEP ORDERING:
It's beneficial to know what you want by the time you get to the window as things move swiftly.  Step 1: Choose your sandwich.  Step 2: Say "wit" AKA "with" if you want grilled onions in your sandwich.  Step 3: Order your cheese type (cheese whiz is the liquid stuff, provolone or American).
 
FOOD:
Mushroom Cheese Steak - $11.04
I got mine wit (onions) and cheese whiz.  The odd price is so that the total rounds up to an even amount with tax.  No time to deal with change here.  Does it live up to the hype?  I say, sure.  I'm not a cheesesteak aficionado but I thought it was good.  The bread was soft, the rough-chopped steak tender and flavorful with the liquid cheese adding more savory notes and the fresh mushrooms a nice earthy flavor.  It's quite a large sandwich, probably close to a footlong but I finished it!  Had I taken time to read the menu better, I would've ordered the sandwich with peppers too. 
 
SERVICE:
It was a chaotic, comical mess but in an organized way LOL.  I've never paid for and received food so quick in my life, literally within 20 seconds.  The guy taking orders was cool, even double checking that I really wanted onions and mushrooms on my sandwich.  I added on sodas but was told it's ordered at the next window.  Wham, bam, thank you ma'am!
 
TIPS:
Cash only.
 
Open 24/7.
 
OVERALL:
It's something you should experience when visiting Philadelphia.  It may not be the best cheese steak around but these guys are legends in their own way.  We'll see how Geno's compares next time.  Follow/friend me and you'll know soon!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Okay, maybe all of the bad rap that Pat's has gotten over the years is dependent on when the critics are going, because I visited late at night on a Thursday (ie, no rush and the place was less active than usual, even though the line was still long) and really didn't have any problem with the servers. That being said, they were still curt with my group, but it was like getting slapped around by a sibling-- do you forgive them immediately? Yes. Welcome to Philly, tourists.

Attitudes (or not) aside, the steaks are big and classic, but they've gotten overpriced over the years and clearly cater to the tourists. A really good buy for that late night grease craving are the fries-- they're crispy and wildly unhealthy at the same time. Better for late night after a concert, when the tourists have left for the day, than for lunch or dinner.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Pat's King of Steaks. Sliced meat with melted American cheese, scantly sprinkled with chopped onions neatly packed into a chewy roll (maybe 5 pieces-to be bitter and hyperbolic). It was surprisingly clean and ordinary. Liked Geno's better because the bread was toasted, the steak was oilier and they gave me a whole lot more onions.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
GROSS 
I will NEVER understand the love for this place. It's gristle with whiz. EW! There are SO many other places to choose from. I hate when this place is recommended for people visiting Philadelphia, too. What an EMBARRASSMENT. Not to mention, the workers are SO rude!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Pat's is a Philly icon and appears on everybody's "best of Philly" bucket list. I ordered the philly cheesesteak with wiz only and fries. The french fries were finger-licking good, extra crispy, and thick cut. The sandwich itself was average, but the bread stood out for being toasted to perfection.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Being from Texas, my husband and I were super excited to try our first true Philly Cheesesteak. We had heard great things about Pat's - so we made a beeline over there to try it out!

When we got there, it seemed we were definitely in the right place. The line was completely around the corner! 

Our mouths were watering - we were so anxious to get to our table and taste this beautiful thing we had heard so much about.

Unforturnately, it was a huge disappointment. The steak tasted a little burned and the bread was super chewy. We realized we must have fallen straight into a tourist trap :-( 

We thought surely a true Philly was better than that - it just had to be.! The next time we were in Philly, we listened to the locals and went to Jim's. Now that - my friends - is a Philly! And the line wasn't nearly as long - even a lunch time!

Wish I could recommend Pat's, but I just can't....
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I've waited my whole life to have a Cheese Steak in Philly. So I went with Pat's it's famous and I've seen it on T.V. boy was I disappointed. The line was long but moved quickly. Seating is limited so if you're with someone grab a seat if there is one open while the other person orders. Cash only luckily there was an ATM across the street. There's a way to order that you must get right before getting to the window. The whole process seems rushed and I noticed it in the food. I got a Cheese Steak with peppers and provolone. The meat was dry and not flavorful like many people say. The cheese didn't have time to melt into the meat even with letting my sandwich sit for a minute. The peppers and onions sat on top so every bite wasn't an even mix of flavors. The fries were okay. Nothing to go bananas about. Will I go there again no. At least I can check it off my list.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
My visiting daughter and family wanted to try some "famous cheesesteaks", so off we went to the two big rivals, right across the street from each other.  The family was all waiting for my daughter and I at Pat's, while we were at Geno's. 

I'll start with first impressions: My daughter desperately needed to use the rest room and Pat's told her to go over to the park adjacent from them!  We did and there was no rest room!  Geno's was right there, so we asked them and they slipped her into the back and left her piddle.

Now we get to friendliness, cleanliness and decor.  Pat's is old and dirty and has not spent one dime of their profits to stand out in these three fields.  Geno's on the other hand has put a lot into these areas.

Now for the cheesesteaks:  Even though we were all headed to Pat's, my daughter and I were so impressed with Geno's that we ordered our steak and fries there. The other 5 in our party stayed at Pat's. 

My daughter and I took our order from Geno's over to Pat's to eat with the others ( tacky for sure and I would have rather ate at Geno's because of the cleanliness and decor). 

First of all, to order a sandwich and fries at Geno's, you must order them and pay for them separately at two different windows,  I can see where this works for them at busy times, but we were the only ones there.  

The meat at Geno's is much, much better than at Pat's.  Everyone, but my stubborn son in law agreed.  The bread is better at Pat's.  The onions are raw at Geno's and sauteed at Pat's.  With a grilled sandwich I would have preferred the sauteed, but I did order a cheesesteak hoagie, so that may be the reason. 

Pat's uses more cheese.  I had provolone. 

All in all, if you add it all up, Geno's definitely has the better of the two cheesesteaks and wins hands down for decor, cleanliness and friendliness.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: it was a cold day! i couldn't enjoy the cheesesteak as much because i was packed in layers of jackets and shivering.  I think it's because it was my first day back in the states coming from the islands, where the weather is always hot and toasty.  We had the cheesesteak with cheese whiz.  I LOVE WHIZ. i would eat more of it right now if i could.  We ate here before picking up some cheese fries from geno's.  The meat was nice and juicy and the bread was very fluffy and warm.  I think i still like Rick's cheesesteaks a bit more from what i remember.  Give me more, i don't mind eating steak all day long especially with the lack of fresh beef in the caribbeans.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
i'll be short since theres tons of reviews on Pat's already. 

So, I never had a real cheese steak. Being from California the closet thing I got to a cheese steak is from the mall food court. Yes insert (laugh). :)

So my advice is if you're not a local and think the mall's philly cheese steak is good, wait until you try this.

Yes, theres a line and its cash only. Theres an atm nearby though. Happy eating.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
2.6/10.0

We tried Pat's instead of Geno's due to the latter's xenophobic publicity in the past.
Haven't heard of the people of Pat's being xenophobic assholes, but the person who took our order when we were there (a Saturday night) was at the least a regular asshole.  

They have obnoxious instructions hanging on the wall that explain how they expect you to order your sandwich.  They are very clear that if you screw up the way they want you to order, they'll send you to the end of the line.

I found this to be off-putting but really got the full experience when I got to the order window.  The employee was purposefully obnoxious--either seeming to go along w/ the all business//wit or witout//whaddayawant routine or, in my opinion, just using that as an excuse to get his own rocks off via  a little cheesesteak order line power trip. It was pathetic.  As soon as I said what I wanted he loudly and rudely corrected what I had said by spitting it out in the Pat's code.  When I asked if he recommended cheese whiz or provolone cheese, he screamed "WHATEVER YOU WANT!".  When I was done ordering the sandwich, he told me to move along.  I asked if I could order a drink as well and he screamed "YOU DON'T DO THAT HERE!.......IN THE OTHER WINDOW!".
It was disgusting.  All I could think was what a loser this cheesesteak order window bully was.  

I've seen others describe the all business/high-stress ordering scenario with stars in their eyes as if it's part of the fun.  Those people are cooked.  Always thought it and it was confirmed when I got to experience it first-hand.  Made me regret giving them my $$ before I even got my mediocre cheesesteak.

The cheesesteak was OK.  Not terribly upsetting, but not the best in Phila.  Ehh.  I'd give the cheesesteak a 7.1/10.0.  I'd give the service and non-eating experience a 0/10.0.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Meeting friends in Philly, was invited to do as many tourists do which was go out for Philly Cheese steaks. As an invited guest, I didnt check Yelp (huge mistake) as to the choice of venue. The only thing I did confirm is that they had a non-beef option...Roasted pork.

Overall, no easy way to put this...But the roasted pork on a hero roll was one of the worst tasting foods I have ever put in my mouth...Or should I say the most tasteless thing I have probably ever eaten. The only positive, if it was a positive was that it wasn't bathed in grease like the beef cheese steaks. The hero roll itself was tasteless and obviously made 1-2 days earlier in some mass production bakery. The roasted pork or what they claimed was roasted pork could better be described as a non-beef steak-umm. It had NO taste whatsoever. Obviously the short-term cooks never heard of salt, pepper, or any spice for that matter. One good thing...The diet soda was able to wash down the barely edible sandwich. 

Unless one is near starvation or every other restaurant in Philly is out of business, one should avoid Pat's
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
So yeah - if you don't live in philly - you're probably going to say Craps (pats) and Beno's (geno's) are the places to go for steaks.  Let me be clear, if you are one of those people: please do us all a favor and jump from the ledge next time you get a chance.  It's bad enough living in the ATL and having to listen to everyone talk about how great these two disasters are.

I may have only eaten at these places a combined 5 or 6 times but i know a tourist trap when i see one.  Two reasons to go to either pat's or geno's: A) You're a tourist and your tour guide is one of the cruelest SOBs on the face of the earth or B) You're smashed and riding shotgun in your buddies pickup truck while driving through philly singing "I'm a Little Teapot"

Okay, so yes I say Craps scores slightly better than that junk across the street... but again - the bar is pretty freakin low here. As i said in my review of Geno's: Either shoot yourself in the face many times over - or go to one of the 300 other spots in the city to get a cheesesteak.  Delessandro's, Tony Lucas, and Steve's come to mind - but there are a slew of others.  And please - this is not about the frekain WIZ.  If you like it with cheese wiz - i won't stand in your way (i've had a few tasty cheeze wiz steaks in my time)... but that does not make Pat's good.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
BACKGROUND OF DECIDING ON PAT'S VS GENO'S:

Final review I'm planning on writing on my Wilmington/Philly Memorial Day weekend trip.  Although I thought of another business I may write a review of in Philly.

Prior to May 2018 trip, I had visited Philly in March 2015, and a friend had recommended Jim's Cheesesteaks on South Street over Pat or Geno's.  I was not a fan of Jim's, which I may write a review on Jim's too if I get around to it.

I did some research into Pat's & Geno's.  I had told my Philly native friend, who lives in the DC area now, that I was thinking one friend could go to one and the other go to the other, and we split the sandwiches, but that would've been a hassle if we had done that.  She strongly recommended Pat's over Geno's criticizing a national news story regarding Geno's.  I didn't really like it either; not enough to boycott but something I took into consideration.  Plus, the reviews were a little better for Pat's.  

Also, when I walked by both, I couldn't even find prices for Geno's, which bothered me.  The prices for Pat's were clearly listed, and while expensive by cheesesteak standards, at least the prices were clearly shown.  Also, Geno's seemed dirtier to me.  

Additionally and perhaps most importantly, there was a historical marker plaque for Pat's saying that the cheesesteak was invited here in 1930.  There was no plaque for Geno's.  This confirmed my decision to go with Pat's. 

EXPERIENCE & FOOD:

My two friends & I waited in line, which was out to the street.  My friend joked we were going to get run over waiting for a cheesesteak, and I further joked that it would be worth it for an excellent authentic cheesesteak.  A guy behind us in line chimed in joking, 'Don't you know? That's how they get their meat!  From the people getting run over.'  I laughed although cannibalism is no laughing matter.

I mentioned to my friends, you may cash, right?  Because this place is cash only.  They both said they had cash.  The guy in front of me in line asked me, 'It's cash only?'  I confirmed it is.  He think he went to the ATM while his g/f or friend he was with held his spot.

The line moved fairly quickly.  Looked like it could've been a 30 minute wait, but it was more like 15 minutes.  We get to the front, and they are very strict about how you order the sandwich.  I said Philly cheesesteak 'Witout Onions' first.  I paid the $11.  They got me the sandwich right away, and simultaneously, I realized I didn't mention the type of cheese I wanted, which I mentioned.  The guy rudely said, "You get cheese whiz; next!"  For the record, I would've gotten provolone, but I was ok with the cheese whiz.  

Something unique was that you ordered the sandwich first and then you went to the second line to get miscellaneous things like drinks, fries, etc.  I figured the sandwich was big, and I didn't need fries.  Also, didn't want to spend $4.50 on a soda I didn't need.  I had already spent $11.

Both my friends got $4.50 soda.  I asked my friend if he could ask for a water cup for me.  I observed them say they didn't have a water cup.  I had a feeling they were going to say that.  Normally, I would be boycotting a place that didn't give a water cup (See my 1-star Popeyes review on 409 8th St SE, Washington DC as an example of that), but I let it slide in this very rare instance because this place was an institution of cheesesteak in Philly.

The Philly cheesesteak was far superior to Jim's, and it was so delicious.  It was unlike any cheesesteak I've had before in my life.  There are maybe 2 or 3 in the DC-Baltimore area that are about equally as good in taste.  But something in the flavor of the meat was really quite amazing with Pat's.  Also, I really liked the Cheese Whiz.

SUMMARY & WATER CONCLUSIONS:
Taste of the food is 5-stars.  Brash customer service & no water cup knocks it down a star to 4-stars.  Overall, I would give this another try since the sandwich was so good.  

Also, after I ate my sandwich, we popped in a convenience store since I was very thirsty.  I paid $0.75 for a bottled water in a convenience store 1 block away.  I had my friends guess the cost.  My Delaware resident friend guessed $3, and my Maryland friend guessed $1.  He said that he could tell by reaction in the store that I was happy with the price.  I told them $0.75, and they were like wow that was good.  I politely reminded them they paid $4.50 for their soda while I paid $0.75 for my water.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: If you love Philly cheesesteaks and want something original THIS is the place to go. Honestly, I do not like Philly cheesesteak sandwiches at all and that is why I only knocked off one star. Me being a person who knows this is not my style of food still was curious and wanted to give this iconic place a try. I made the first mistake by not ordering without onions ‍. If you go, and are a rookie, pay attention to the sign to listed to the right where you order, it tells you how you should order. I only ate probably 1/3 of the sandwich before I couldn't eat anymore (the onions really got to me). The 3 other people I was with finished my sandwich, theirs, and another from a competitors location. (According to them there was no competition and that this was hands down the best Philly cheesesteak in existence). Also, bring cash!!!!! Most places like this and even around Philly only accept cash so be sure to always carry around some extra cash.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: We ordered a "Philly Cheese Steak Sandwich"  ..............tourists.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
It's ok. That's it. It doesn't deserve to be king, but it is better than Geno's. Decent amount of meat on the cheesesteak,  which I guess is cool, but i wish it had more flavor. I should have asked for extra cheese. That is the redeeming quality I've discovered after my third cheesesteak in a single weekend. 
Went on a Saturday night. Zero line. Plenty of seating outside. 
Do yourself a favor and go to Tony Luke's
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I didn't enjoy a cheesesteak here. I ended up taking a deep breath, hitting the ATM and going across the street to Gino's. My boyfriend and I had never visited either establishment, and didn't know what to expect.. didn't have cash and was so excited by the thrill of things that I ordered and didn't know it was cash only. 

Let me just start off with.. I don't care where you have your cash only signs. All of your lines block things. 

Also, After going both places unnoticed there is a complete disregard of the fact that most of their clientele is tourists who may have not been before and don't know what they are doing so why be so rude when ordering and why make it so quick to the point where the person ordering can't even breathe? Ridiculous lack of customer service if you ask me... after all I do feel you should take the time to get to know your tourist clientele. They are probably the only ones keeping you in business. Won't be back, not interested.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
My first Philly cheesesteak experience was... underwhelming.

I ordered the whiz without and as I ate it, I could only think of the various sandwiches I've had in my life that taste better (nearly all of them).

The bread is bland, the steak is bland and the Cheez Whiz is.. well... Cheez Whiz.

Arby's is better.  Potbelly is way better.  Subway is better.  And after I walked across the street, even Geno's is better.

It's worth swinging by Pat's just to see the weird collection of people there (girls in prom dresses, tourists, bikers, probable gang members), but your food is going to be a disaster.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: After a night out in the city this would be ideal fill your belly and don't eat a MISTEAK
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Always make this a stop when I get back home in the Philly area. I go with the wiz without and cheese fries. Even when it is 20 degrees out, the outdoor seating is just fine when you have a pat's steak in your hand. Geno's sucks!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
We all know, you can't come to Philly and not have a cheesesteak.  In my opinion, Pat's is a lot better than Geno's. The reason is, I like the steak chopped up in my cheesesteaks. Over at Geno's it;s more like slabs of meat. I also liked the flavor of the steak at Pat's as well.  To each its own. They were both good, it just comes down to personal preference. I did stop by Jim's but didn't like it one bit. It was tasteless and a waste of the hour we spent in line. 

Just like my Pink's hot dog review, Pat's is not just a place to eat, it's an experience!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Best Philly Cheese steak I've ever had! My husband brought the family to this place and it was a great experience. From what I hear there are always people lined up outside this place and now I know why... But get this, these guys are literally making your order as soon as the words fall from your mouth... Hot & Ready! What really tipped me over the edge was that these guys had GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE and that's what sets them apart from the competition in my opinion.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: There's no shortage of steak or cheese on the sandwich, nor is there a shortage of cheese on the fries. Bring cash, and be prepared to pay AT LEAST $15 a pop. Drinks are like frickin $3.50, and you don't even get free refills. My wife and I both really enjoyed our sandwiches and fries, but this is a place you only go to like once when you're in town.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: What a huge disappointment. So expensive to. I was on a mission to try both. Both are a waste of money. Both was $32.00 and worth $3.00 WAWA IS SO MUTCH BETTER! Yes! WAWA! WAWA is like a 7/11. I hang my head in shame. What a waste of Cab fare. Driver..... take me to WAWA.... near South St. Thanks Yelp
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Wife and I were excited to stop here at such an institution.  We were traveling from NYC and stopped at Pat's and split a cheesesteak - with onions and cheese wiz.  After we ate by the way we went across the street and split a Geno's cheesesteak to compare (Pat's won the battle but not by much - and not that great).

We were extremely disappointed with the quality of the meat.  It was very chewy and tough.  Completely lacking any seasoning or taste whatsoever.  The roll was ok but not toasted or that fresh.  The onions were ok.  The big thing that is surprising that there is no camelization on the meat or onions - it was more like they were boiled.

Overall it was very unremarkable generic tasting food.  We've got better cheesesteaks down in Florida.  Next visit in town we will try Sonny's.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Yeah, I guess it's kinda like going to the Wiener's Circle for a Chicago Style hot dog, accompanied by a verbal assault when you come to Chicago. Just ask for ketchup on your dog and you'll see what I mean. Same at Pat's King of Steaks, so allow me a little tourist action, Philly. I was brought here by a seasoned local anyway! 

I loved my Steak with Cheese Whiz and onions. And accidentally did not follow the Rules and ordered my fries at the Steak window! Aw, geez, boss! Yeah, that wasn't good! But the cheese steak was! We can't get an authentic cheese steak in Chicago, so, thanks boss!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Philly hype!  Had to stop by and try a historic Cheese Steak. From the two window ordering set up to the stringy over cooked steak, not a great experience.  The roll was tough, the meat was just in the middle of the sandwich and they must think the cheese wiz is made of gold. Fries were good, even though you have to order them from a different place than the sandwich.  Very inconvenient.  Three stars just because the atmosphere and outdoor seating is cool.  Ambience should be a bonus, not the reason for visiting.  Food should always be the draw.  Raise your game Pat's!   Have to try Geno's next time.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Ignore all negative comments and stop by Pat's when in Philly.  The way I see it, there are two main groups of haters.  First are a group of  some (not all) people who are elitist cheese steak snob locals that say "Pat's is touristy and [insert another local shop name here] is so much better."  And second, are a group of people who are used to their regional cheesesteak styles that may include strange cheeses and newfangled toppings like alfa alfa sprouts and God know what else that do not belong on a true Philadelphia cheesesteak and disappointed with Pat's.  

To the first group I say. Give credit where credit is due.  There's a reason why Pat's has been a Philly staple for almost a 100 years (okay  more like 88 years) and they have lines out to wazoo at all times of day.

To the second group I say; YOU HAVE BEEN DECEIVED. The authentic Philly cheesesteak on the menu at your local Friday's or hole in the wall sandwich shop is NOT, I repeat, NOT a Philly cheesesteak.  A true Philly cheesesteak should be served on a local hoagie roll (usually Amoroso's) with thin juicy slices of season ribeye steak, sauteed onions, and cheese whiz.  That's it.  No mayo, no ketchup, no lettuce, no banana peppers, no hot sauce... No! Just no. Stop it. Saying Geno's is bad because you are used to your local area cheesesteaks is like going to China and saying the food there sucks because you like Panda Express. 

Anyways. I love Pat's.  They consistently whip me up a nice juicy cheese whizzy cheesesteak. Anytime I'm in philly I make sure I stop by.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Could rate it 5 on a 10 scale, but will round it down to a 2 star rating instead of 3, because this place gets plenty of hype already and the counter guy had an attitude. Pat's is better than Geno's. Still , I have had better. The bread was meh. The meat was decent. THe cheesewiz was well... cheesewiz. Travel shows need to stop hyping these two joints. I had to add a little black pepper to the meat. Seasoning is meh.

I asked the guy politely if he could slice it threeways. The dude purposely just slices it two ways and when I asked again if he could cut it one more time, he gave me a rude response saying maybe my friends should just stop being cheap and buy their own sandwich. What the jagoff should realize was we already had other sandwiches and what we planned to do with the sandwich was none of his business.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Ok so my nephew bought me one of these cheese steaks and also one from Geno's. They were both very good, very cheesy and both breads excellent. They both were loaded with lots of cheese and steak. But Pat's sandwich had an unmistakable flavor of sweet onions that's hard to miss. So if you like the taste of sweet onions this is the one for you. On the other hand if you don't like onions then Gino's is for you. In my humble opinion both are delicious and worth the trip.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: By far this place is mediocre. I want to eat the original PHILADELPHIA Steak sandwich but it didn't cut it.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Not great at all. Coming from the West coast I was excited to try the original. Bread was good, meat had no flavor. Definitely a disappointing experience. Won't come back.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Went on a Philly Food Tour this past weekend and Gino's and Pat's were my first stops. Of course, I couldn't help but compare the two...
Service: Gino's. Hands down!
Bread: Gino's. Sooo fresh, great texture. Delicious!
Meat: Pat's. They give you more.
Cheese: Pat's. Again, They give ya more.
Sandwich overall: Pat's. 
The Geno's cheesesteak was dripping...I guess juice from the meat. The Pat's cheesesteak was dripping cheeeeeese. When I'm in Philly, I'll be gettin' BOTH Pat's and Geno's cos they're both great in their own ways.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Disgusting!! Never ever again.. this was the worst cheese steak I've ever had. The meat tasted like it had been reheated several times before it was served to me.. old and dry... I can't believe they have the nerve to called one of Philly's best cheese steaks restaurant.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Cash only. If you like a cold cheese steak with non-melted cheese, as well as an unfriendly server, this is a top place to frequent. Could not care less about the Gino's or Pat's comparisons. However, Gino's was served hot, the staff were so friendly, and the cheese steak is a dollar cheaper for some reason. Maybe an off-day but there was a staff of eight when we got to Pat's. To serve two cheesesteaks frigid cold literally is quite poor quality.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: It's definitely one of the finest examples but don't kid yourselves into believing this is the best. There are plenty of other places far exceed this version. The place across the street is basically the same
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Lines are long and theres nothing fancy. Even tho the lines are long they move very fast. There isn't any special spices or many options. What you will get is a soul satisfying taste of really good steak and a spatula of liquid goldand amazing bread. The Wiz isnt good for you. Its salty and oooozzy but it is the blanket that wraps you up and tells you that everything is going to be ok. It brings the sandwich together. Its the reason you order the sandwich. It will warm you up when you come here on a cold winters day. 

Are there fancier cheesteaks (Yes)


But there is something about the father of cheesteaks that will keep you coming for years. I LOVE PATS.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Very greasy and overrated. Paid $22 for two cheesesteaks and another $12 for two fountain sodas and a small cup of fries. It's definitely a one time stop just to say we went but will never go back
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Disclaimer: one of our team members tends to be overly-critical.

That being said, our visit to Pat's was awesome! The cheesesteaks were delicious -- the bread was perfect for soaking up the whiz and the steak was so good. You gotta go to Pat's! Plus, Geno's is racist soooo there's only one right decision. 

The reason this doesn't get a 5 is because (despite objections from the Philly native in our group that this criticism is blasphemy) it was really freaking cold and there is no indoor option. Our hands really got so frozen while trying to do the thing where you use your finger to lick up all the cheesy cheese on the wrapper.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I know that this place is advertised as one of the best place to get a cheesesteak hoagie.  It is not.  If you want a thin piece of cheap steak (whole) on a bun and you put on condiments, then this is the place for you.  

In my humble opinion, this is a tourist trap.  If you are a Philly person, you know this is not a great place for cheesesteak bogies.  If you are a tourist and you just want to go to see for yourself, please go, just know that the food is not all that it is advertised.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
I'm sure there are better cheesesteaks in the wonderful city of Philly, but I'm more facinated by the age old competition between Pat's & Geno's. 

So who makes the better (not best) cheesesteak? All hats go to Pat's for 2 reasons: The meat portion is larger & the texture is greasier. In my opinion, Geno's excelled in the flavor department but I didn't like the fact that it has less meat compared to Pat's. Also, both sandwiches cost the same at $7.50. 

I do recommend you order it "wid" onions & provolone cheese in place of the non-organic cheez whiz.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: None better.  No need to go across street to Genos.  It's always my first stop when I come back home!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: LOVED IT. I was with two other people and we shared a cheesesteak at both Pat's and Geno's. I liked Pat's better, personally, but another person in my group liked Geno's. Get the cheese whiz - it adds great flavor.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
There's NO better... waited in a line wrapped around the building last night and it was more than worth it. 

Do yourself a favor and go! 

PS-- don't be fooled by Geno's flashy lights... you want Pat's!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Yes I know it may be a tourist trap but everytime I find myself in Philly, I usually make a trip out to Pat's if I can - it's definitely the novelty and I'm sure you can find better cheesesteaks elsewhere but Pat's is definitely is up there and to have good memories with friends to go along with it - I'll take it =)

First off I've tried both Pat's and Geno's - unless you've completely lost all your taste buds through old age or eating way too much hot sauce - Pat's is the clear winner. The meat is chopped rather than in dry slices like Geno's. The bread at Pat's is also more toasted. Plus any place that surrounds itself in neon lights like a mini times square is overcompensating for something.

I usually get the original cheesesteak - wit whiz (with onions and cheese whiz) - amazing! Prices have gone up though to 9.50+ a sandwich - I was lucky to come when there was no line, if I had to wait more than 30 mins - probably would reconsider. 

Overall great place to get your cheesesteak fix
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Fifteen years ago, when my pudgy, middle-school mouth got its very first taste of a cheesesteak it was a provolone with from Pat's... and the bill came to a cool $5.25.

The price has changed, of course, but Pat's has remained basically the same. Overrated? Sure. Snarky, no-frills attitude? Of course. Delicious-as-hell? You betcha. But that's all part of the recipe for a perfect cheesesteak. Good service isn't about being polite and wearing a fake smile--it's about always getting your food in less than five seconds and being open 24/7. Because nothing's better than a cheesesteak for breakfast at four in the morning.

Side note: I've never been to Geno's, nor do I want to. Maybe it's their ridiculous neon lighting, or their borderline obsession with police memorabilia... ah, who am I kidding. It's their "This is America: WHEN ORDERING PLEASE SPEAK ENGLISH" sign that guarantees I'll never be a customer.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Authentic cheesesteaks delicious!
We came here After spending the day in Philly and we ordered three cheesesteaks with. The staff was super friendly and the location was nicely tucked away in a neighborhood. 
The staff was super friendly and it was nice that their was some outside seating available.
Can't wait to return to South philly to  eat these again.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Pat's vs Geno's?  All hype, they're both just ok.  I can't tell if there's clearly one better than the other.  I ordered the same thing at both, Philly cheesesteak with onions and provolone.  Pat's in my left hand, Geno's in my right.  The bread looks the same.  Pat's meat is shredded, Geno's is thinly sliced.  Was it worth the wait at the two, no!  The guys at Geno's were clearly nicer.  Was it fun running back and forth? I think so.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Thus far I have only been to Philly one time. So I am not the best judge. But I do love cheesesteaks. Maybe there are better local places to grab a cheesesteak. But with so many options, if you're from out of town like me and don't know which one to choose you will likely want to at least try one of the two most iconic spots in Philadelphia. Genos or Pats. They are similar, main difference of how their meat is sliced. Genos - sliced, Pats is more chopped , which personally I find to me better and more tender. The provolone is nice and sharp, the cheese wiz - amazing and the peppers have a roasted sweetness that's awesome. The bread is delicious. It was worth the three hour drive, the several block walk in freezing temperatures, the waiting in line of 25 people and eating outside in the cold. Very worth it. In my humble cheesesteak opinion. Best tip: know what you want BEFORE you get to the counter. They serve thousands of those things a day and don't have time for uncertain dawdlers to make up their mind. Use google, read the menu before you get in line or use this review: do you want a steak, a cheesesteak, or peppers and mushrooms  ? What kind of cheese do you want: Wiz (cheesewiz/ liquid cheddar) American, provolone- or all three. And with or without onions. Those are your choices. You order and pay for just the cheesesteaks at the first window and drinks or sodas at the next one. It's not super cheap and it's cash only. Come prepared. Genos across the street is the same price for the cheesesteaks so if you're over there looking for a better deal cost wise- think again. Pats only has outdoor eating.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Driest cheesesteak I've had in all of Philly. Barely edible. Pat's and Geno's are collectively the Kim Kardashian of Philly cheesesteak joints.

I had the cheesesteak with provolone, mushrooms, and peppers. Eating the meat was like eating sandpaper. I know Pat's is a Philly staple, but it's more of a check off the box for a tourist. It's famous for the sake of being famous. If you're looking for a good cheesesteak, trek a few blocks north to Jim's on South Street.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Pat's is an experience that both requires and gives some perspective.  I say that because, prior to getting a cheese steak at Pat's, I always assumed that all of my previous cheese steak experiences were sub par because I had been dealing with sub par cheese steaks.  However, after eating at Pat's--the reported best--I gained the perspective that cheese steaks are what they are, and I'm just not the biggest cheese steak fan in the world.  So the question becomes:  was Pat's really not that good, or was Pat's really good at something I just don't care about.

I  think the answer lies somewhere in the middle.  As my friend Chris R. told me, Pat's cheese steaks are the ones for the tourists and the ones for foodies are located somewhere else.  So, I'm not about to give up on cheese steaks.  Chris also told me that a 3 am Pat's stop should be on the itinerary for a trip to Philly so it wasn't a wasted trip.  Taken as a 3am snack, I think I'd rather just get a waffle at a diner.

All in all, it's just an ok sandwhich.  It's a pretty cool experience though, waiting in line at 3 am with the late night, rowdy crowd where what you're wearing doesn't matter, and the only thing that does is if your doing wiz or american, and wit or witout...i just wish any of those combinations resulted in a 4 star plate.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: What a waste! I was in Philly for a few days with my family and decided to give this place a try because of how "well known" it was. My family & I ordered 5 sandwiches, and to be honest.. they all really sucked. Dry, no flavor, it just tasted like you were eating bread. Not to mention that it was $10 for just the sandwich with no fries or drink... I would never go back here and would tell visitors their money would be better spent elsewhere
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
first time having a steak with whizz. not sure i have ever been the same since. 

it is what it is, a greasy fatty sandwich, the type that i love.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Not so sure how Pat was deemed "King of Steaks". I ordered a mushroom pepper cheesesteak with onions and cheese wiz. I don't know if it was the cheese, meat, or bread, but something about it just tasted off. It actually left me feeling queasy. I went to Max's last time I was in Philly, and it tasted more fresh and flavorful. I would recommend Max's over Pat's any day. Maybe Max should be the new king...
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I have a recollection of this being juicy and greasy and a guilty pleasure delicious, but my last order was pretty dry (other than the whiz of course) and was not a huge fan of the meat. Either I was wrong or this has changed, but either way I won't be checking out pats again any time soon.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Wow. This was the best cheese steak I've ever had. Bear in mind, I'm a Georgia boy with little cheese steak experience, but I am a big foodie. I got extra steak "wit" onions and whiz and then got some of those hot peppers on the side. I sat right there and ate the whole thing, and it was cold as nads out there. This place is really something.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
So while in Philadelphia I decided to go cheesesteak hunting.  I watched a couple reviews and read some articles about where to go and decided on three places: Pat's King of Steaks, Tony Luke's and Woodrow's.  

So Pat's, what a let down. Really the only thing they are doing right is the speed in service. But the steak was over cooked, the onions ok, bread was a bit chewy and it was severely lacking on the cheese wiz.  Really sad about this one.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
'Wit Whiz." Translation: Steak sandwich with sauteed onions and cheese whiz. When you finally reach the window at Pat's, you'd better be ready to order or ya might get hassled.

For my first trip to Philly, naturally I had to have the cheesesteak, Pat's and Geno's being the two biggest names on the block - literally. These two cheesesteak giants are right next to each other. I chose Pat's because my host for the weekend said it was better and it had a longer line.

After a long day running around being a tourist, when I got my cheesesteak I couldn't wait to scarf it down. The hot peppers and hot sauce added to the experience a bit, but honestly I now realize I'm not a big cheesesteak fan in general. I guess that means I'm just not meant to live in Philly.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I loved Pat's! Fast and easy. Recommend to anyone who is looking for a good philly cheesesteak!
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: It's a classic, and I prefer it to Geno's, but there are many better options out there. The bread is OK but not warmed up and ends up being both a little too chewy and crunchy. The meat is decent quality but slightly thickly sliced for my preference. It's chopped decently - not too fine or coarse, which is good. A respectable effort, day in and day out - not the best around, but at 1AM it might be the only option nearby.. and it'll definitely do the trick then.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
One word describes this place - shit.  

I'll go to Jim's or Tony Luke's next time like I know I should have.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Better than the las vegas strip across the street in terms of taste ... but the place is a dump , and the people there treat you like shit  but then again its still not half as bad as if you go across the street, and speak with the slightest HINT of an accent.

Pricey, dirty, but tasty .. and like ive said bafore there are better steaks out therem where they actualy wipe the tables
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: I will make damn sure I never go to Pat's again and will tell my family and friends the same. My female friend ordered some cheesesteaks to go and was asked to hang out with the guys at the counter for a while. She declined because it was cold and the guy at the counter said he would keep her warm. Again, she declined and said she's happily married. Then the guy got short with her. Finally, when she asked for her change the guy pulled it back and said he needed a hug before she could have it. She declined again and asked for her change two more times before he finally handed it over.  Maybe explain to the workers what harassment is and that holding someone's change hostage so the creepy jerk at the counter can get a hug is at best unethical and worst sexual harassment.  She didn't want me to post this, but no one deserves to be made to feel that uncomfortable.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text:
Being an out of towner, I wanted to try a famous philly cheesesteak. I didn't know I had to order one in the local vernacular. 

Got whiz wit.....it was ok, kinda small for the price. I think I've had better in NYC.
categories: Italian, American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Fast Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Cheesesteaks

name: Pat's King of Steaks
text: Came specifically to Philly for this!! For a place claiming to be the inventors of the cheesesteak, I expected way more. They are super overpriced for the quality that you are getting ($11), it was the most bland sandwich I've had. The steak was dry and had no flavor and the bread sucked.
